description:
We saw their review on "Check Please" and decided to give them a try. 
We visited Portugal couple of years ago and we loved the food there. We have been looking out for good Portuguese food ever since. 

This place did not disappoint us. We were impressed with their service and food quality. Great place for a date night. We loved the classic Portuguese dishes like piri piri chicken, Mozambique gambas and bacalhau fritters. They also have a good selection of Portuguese wines like white and red vino verde and also the rose wines.
Our wait staff was excellent. He gave us a good overview of their dishes and some good recommendations. This place can get busy and reservation is recommended.
author: Raman S.

description:
Saw this on check please and instantly decided it would be perfect for a lovely dinner with friends. 

David was our server and he was very knowledgeable and attentive. He helped guide us through a tasty evening. I hope you experience his service, he made us feel comfortable during our first visit.

We started with the home made bread & butter. It was freshly baked and the olive butter was a delicious pairing.

We followed that with the heirloom tomato salad. Organic hand picked tomatoes, feta cheese, cucumbers dashed with a red wine vinaigrette.

The pork ribletts were a great compliment to the salad. They were so juice and fall off the bone, it was out of this world 

We chose a medium sized and full plate entree to round out the meal. The lamb dish had a tasty chutney with some spicy peppers that added some heat to the meal.

The half oven roasted chicken dish with French fries and aioli was something I saw on check please. Wow, it was good. When I come back next time, that is a definite must. If a chicken has a nice flavored, crunchy crust and moist white meat inside, it's an A+ in my book.

Next time we will be having a seafood dish, I spied from my table that the sea bass looked amazing.

Desert was on point. 

I left feeling satisfied and not too full. Just what I needed.
author: Ryan G.

description:
Not bad , food good , drinks over priced.
Port was advertised as 20year old but I'm sure it was cheap tawny.
Service was great and helpful .
author: Jeremy P.

description:
We enjoyed Uma Casa and while the dishes were hit and miss the overall experience was a fun dinning one.

Uma Casa is a fun and pretty little place to grab good Portuguese comfort food dishes.

Hits: 
Salt Cod fritters with cilantro Mayo: Crispy outside soft tender inside great with beer and their dipping sauce.

Arugula Salad was refreshingly fresh and the cheese added was delicious.

Pan seared Octopus. While the octopus was slightly overcooked the flavor was great and the greens served with it melded to make a good dish.

Braised pork shoulder, linguicia, and clams. How can you not like a dish with all those ingredients? The broth is really good and you can sop it up with the bread...really good!

Misses:

The Branzino: they did not debone it and it was a total pain to eat. The fish was great but the bones killed it. Loved the potatoes with it.

The Sardines were also just  a not good dish. I've had some amazing sardines and these just were not great.

Finally the desserts were totally a fail. The pastry dough dessert was impossible to eat and listless. The egg tarts were totally forgettable .

Definelty come with a group of people to try several dishes and stick with the small plates.

Great service and ambiance  gives these guys 4 stars ( that plus Portugal losing to Uruguay...sympathy star!)
author: David G.

description:
My lovely husband is Portuguese--Azorean, baby! We've been to the Azores, and we desperately want to go back. When he found out about this restaurant, we KNEW we had to try it; we popped in right before we went to watch Les Mis.

What I love: the decor. Omg. The lighting, the airy feel, and those Portuguese tiles sent me over the moon! I left wanting to tell my interior designer that I needed Portuguese tiles for my backsplash in my kitchen.

The food: this is a gourmet approach to authentic Portuguese cuisine, and we loved it.

We got several items, and I think we got too much! We got the caldo verde and our waitress brought it out in two bowls for us. I thought the caldo verde had great flavor and I loved the oil. The shrimp turnovers were YUMMY. My husband got the polvo (octopus), and he thought the cornmeal crust was a nice touch. It was light and not overbearing. The presentation of the polvo was outstanding. The bacalhau was different from what we'd eaten in the past, but we enjoyed it. We liked how the olives were minced and not whole. The piri piri chicken was grilled/roasted to perfection, the side salad had GREAT, light dressing, and the french fries were phenomenal.

We had a great experience here, and we can't wait to take my husband's mom and dad here!

Obrigado, Uma Casa!
author: Chandra D.

description:
I loved visiting Portugal and it's rare to find a Portuguese restaurant in the US. When a Portuguese colleague let me know Uma Casa existed--woo hoo. It's a great take on upper scale Portuguese food. If you haven't tried it before, its like Spanish only spicier.

Overall a great place and experience.  The pluses:
1) The shrimp: GAMBAS MOÇAMBIQUE.  Outstanding, they use the malagueta pepper which imparts a unique and amazing flavor--and heat. A very nice variation on a traditional dish.
2) Shrimp turnovers:  On the heavy side, but very nice flavor.
3) PÃO COM MANTEIGA: Chorizo and olive butter on the toasted, house made bread--very nice flavors.
4) Service--our waitress was attentive, knew the menu and rolled the food out at a nice, controlled pace.

Minuses:
1)  Normally I like Vinho Verde.  They had "high end" Vinho Verde here, about $60/bottle.  I sampled a few of the Vinho Verdes here. At home, I drink Vinho Verde for its light fruitiness, the wine here tasted like it was mixed with Chardonnay.  I'm not a Chard fan so for me it was a let down. (The next day I got a $9 bottle at my local wine store and it was better.
2) The calamari/cucumber salad as a miss.  Squid was chewy and not pleasant.
3) OK, not a complaint about Uma Casa: we were seated in between people who were on the phones the whole time.  WTF?  I don't get it. Leave your phone at home--talk to each other.  Communicate. We're people.

Note that I went all seafood so no comments (yet) on the meat dishes.

Overall, I'll be back and encourage anyone try Uma Casa--but without your phone.
author: Rob R.

description:
I was surprised that my boyfriend and I managed to be seated right away at 7:00 pm on a Friday night, given that Uma Casa has a reputation for being packed. A woman who was seated next to us mentioned the same thing as she sat down, but it didn't take long for the place to get full. Be prepared to yell across your tiny table to have a conversation here.

It took a while for our waitress to come around after we were seated, and when she finally showed up she was acting like she had something better to do than wait our table and sullenly asked if we wanted still or sparkling water. She never welcomed us or even told us her name - she was just the sulky brunette with the nose piercing. She brought out some complimentary house made potato chips and an amazing dipping sauce, which I believe was the house piri piri sauce. Spicy, bright, with just a hint of citrus, I wanted more chips so I could continue to eat it.

We started with the pasteis de bacalhau (salt cod fritters with cilantro mayo) which were an immediate disappointment. While the outsides of the fritters were crispy, the inside was a little chewy and pasty. Not good. The cilantro mayo was underwhelming and tasted little of cilantro.

Next came the caldo verde, which was a marked improvement above the fritters. Unlike some recipes, which call for chunks of potato, Uma Casa's caldo verde incorporates potato into the soup as a thickener so every spoonful tastes of potato. The linguica was meaty and the collard greens were cooked perfectly.

It took quite a while for the next dish to come and I thought our waitress forgot about it. We finally got the pao e manteiga (house made bread with olive and chorizo butters), which was a simultaneous hit and miss. The bread was fantastic, served warm from the oven and slightly toasted. The olive butter was a fruity, creamy spread that I kept reaching for, but the chorizo butter was really not working for me. The first bite I took tasted like plain butter, but on the second bite I got distinct chorizo flavor and wasn't a fan. Maybe it was the thought of mixing meat and butter into a paste, coupled with the fact that the butter was so room temperature it was almost warm, but I prefer to eat my chorizo as a solid meat rather than creamed into butter.

Again, there was a lengthy wait between the bread and our main courses; while waiting, the woman next to us ordered a steak but the waiter informed her they were sold out. Her husband asked why they were sold out of steak at 8:20, mirroring my thoughts exactly. The polvo dourado finally came out: an octopus tentacle, lightly breaded in cornmeal, curled in the middle of the plate with greens, a single radish slice (yes, one), and three stalks of asparagus, in a sauce that may have been piri piri. This was some of the best octopus I've ever had, so tender it almost melted in your mouth and paired really well with the asparagus and greens.

The frango piri piri (chicken in a piri piri sauce with greens and fries) was a sizable dish that was shareable among two people. The chicken was incredibly tender and married perfectly with the spicy flavors in the piri piri sauce. The acidic vinaigrette on the greens was a great pairing with the heat of the chicken, and I used the piri piri sauce we were given with the chips at the start of the meal to dip the chicken in for some additional flavor. The thin cut fries were fantastic and soaked up some of the juices from the chicken.

Our dinner plates were cleared and our waitress came by with dessert menus; it's rare that I don't want to look at a dessert menu so I was grateful she brought them, but also took notice of the fact that she didn't ask if we wanted dessert, she just dropped the menus in front of us and left. We shared the tarte de chocolate with spiced cream and espresso gelato. Very little about this dessert was good. The gelato - the best part - was the tiniest serving of gelato I've ever been served, while the spiced cream spread over the entire tart completely overwhelmed all the other flavors on the plate. I couldn't fully appreciate the espresso flavor of the gelato, and had I been blindfolded I might've thought I was eating pumpkin pie. Hardly any of the chocolate suffocating under the cream came through, and the crust was way too hard to cut into with a spoon.

After dessert our waitress dropped the check on the table and left without a word. She didn't ask us if we'd like anything else, didn't do a final check in to make sure the meal went well. She also never thanked us. That's wait staff etiquette 101.

The meal was pricey. Before tip it came out to $107, but I didn't enjoy the food enough to feel it was worth it. Weird waitress, pretty out of the way (had to take BART and then MUNI), frustratingly slow service (I don't want to be rushed during a meal but I also don't want to be held hostage at my table for 2 hours with little interaction from any wait staff). I wouldn't return even if I were in the area.
author: Angela M.

description:
Had a great treat, four course dinner on Wednesday the 10th October.
Preparations were great and authentic. Salmon was cooked so nicely that you rarely get to eat at other places.
Chef was courteous, knowledgeable and friendly.
Expensive yes, but worth it for the service  product  and easy parking
author: Hari B.

description: Shrimp empanadas type dish is delicious, sausage cabbage soup, halibut great, smoked marinated bbqd chicken wonderful flavor & texture, fab octopus tentacle with sauce superbly made, great sparkling wines of Portugal
author: Syrah F.

description:
Kicking off the new year by bringing you a tale of the WARMEST FUZZIEST FEELS EVER. You're probably wondering how a food review could possibly have anything to do with sentiments, but I promise I'll tie these two together shortly.

The story takes place during every Yelper's favorite time of the year - Restaurant Week. My friend had a reservation for two to try the Restaurant Week menu at Uma Casa, but on the day of, her mounting foodie excitement was cut short when she was abruptly laid off from her job with no notice. When the restaurant texted to confirm her reservation, she asked to cancel given her recent job loss. Uma Casa responded back in the most generously compassionate manner inviting her to keep her reservation and dine on the house. 

From the minute we entered, we were warmly greeted by the ebullient Luca, who was full of encouraging, positive energy. Even though Luca was not our waiter, he continued to check in on us periodically throughout the night and pretty soon, his infectious personality had evolved my friend's dejected mood into lighthearted optimism. 

The restaurant itself reflected Luca's affable nature - even though the decor was classy, it didn't lose its intimate, personable feel of dining in a comfortable, welcoming environment as we were surrounded by boisterous laughter and conversation in a dimly lit space. We sampled several dishes from the menu, but the standouts would definitely be 1) the salada de mariscos, a ceviche like cold dish packed with shrimp, octopus, squid, and beans, and 2) the bacalhau gomes de sa, a baked salt cod dish with perfectly balanced flavors.

Thank you Uma Casa, and Luca, for filling our bellies and warming our hearts!
author: Jenni H.

description:
Huge hit in my book! We came here for our anniversary dinner and LOVED everything we tried. 

Salt cod fritters - we could have eaten a zillion plates of these little buggers!
Octopus - omg, where have you been all my life!
Shrimp - obvs.
Lamb chorizo - yes, please.
Milho frito - why not?
Tuna tartare - duh.
Beef short rib - so tender and juicy!

Yes, we over indulged. But it was WORTH.IT.

Can't wait to go back and get some more salt cod fritters...I mean, try other things on the menu too.. :)
author: Jessica M.

description:
Pricey but tasty.
I liked at this restaurant is bold to open the door to grade amazing Portugues tastes both food and wine
author: Nuno S.

description:
Christine C brought me here and it was a delight!  It's the first Portuguese restaurant in SF.  I personally was unaware of Portuguese cuisine except for the custard tart, but this cute little place blew me away.  

DINNER
Miyagi oysters
Gulf shrimp
Duck confit risotto
Braised short ribs
Salt cod fritters
Portuguese custard tart

There's a very nice ambiance at Uma Casa, from the mosaic tiles to the lovely wait staff.  They were very helpful in guiding us with our meal choice and I was happy with our experience.  At first I didn't think we were going to be full, but it ended up being just enough for the two of us.
author: Lyn C.

description:
Oof. This one was a miss. The food was fine (other than dessert which was bad to the point of almost inducing spontaneous vomiting), maybe even better than fine, but overall a miserable experience. Probably half-full but only one waiter and he was very much overtaxed. Actually, back to food, it's just a few days later and I don't remember anything we ate so maybe that says more about the food than I thought.

The space seems to be unsure of itself. Seemingly a lot of holdover from restaurants past in this location. Not combining into anything in particular decorwise though.

It was FREEZING. Note: a waiter apologizing does not fix that. Everyone was sitting with their sweaters or winter coats on and still very cold. "Well, it's so rarely this cold in SF so the owners didn't want to spend the money to address the draft" is not valid. Close if you don't want to fix it. At least close on nights where it's too cold. It's nice that you brought in a space heater for the guy at the front desk (or otherwise he probably would've frozen) but bring in a few more or something for the guests. 

My friend and I were going to suffer in silence but then the two separate groups next to us complained which let us all then commiserate. 

The location: not enough of a draw. Not sure why there is anything in this space. Neighborhood dead, so remote, not easy to see what it is. This isn't going to be the NOPA that brings up the whole neighborhood - it's a location that will just continue to shut down whatever opens there. 

Won't ever be going back, can't recommend anyone else giving it a try.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Had a really good experience dining at this place.  Nice decors and ambiance. Very efficient service staff and we are well taken cared of.  And the important thing, food is really good too.

We ordered:
OSTRAS (raw half-dozen oysters) - from Tomales Bay, really fresh and the piri-piri sauce is so good with it!
PASTEIS de BACALHAU (salt cod fritters) - its good and a must try.
POLVO DOURADO (cornmeal crusted octopus) - my husband noted that its tender and we both liked it very much, would love to get a little bigger portion though but other than that, its really good and well prepared.
PEIXE do DIA (pan roasted daily catch) - the daily catch for that day was halibut, we kind of waited for about 10 more minutes from when our last dish was taken but it was cooked well, the salsa that came with it complemented it really well and even the sweet potato is good with it.  It is a good sized portion.
PASTEL de NATA (Portuguese egg custard tart) - to end the meal, we had the popular egg custard tart, I feel like its a bit sweet but sharing one with my husband is just perfect.  Not too much not too little.

We shared everything that we ordered and its a good portion for a not-too-heavy dinner for two people. 

Will definitely recommend to anyone looking for Portuguese cuisine.
author: Abby Q.

description:
Uma Casa is serving up delicious Portuguese tapas that are worthy of sharing with a group of friends. The ambiance itself is worthy of falling for, but the food is the real star here. Now, I'll preface this by saying that Uma Casa was the second stop in our SF food adventure, so we had eaten small dishes at another restaurant before coming here. As a result, a small sampling of some of the recommended dishes was more than enough for us. 

We ordered:
+ Salt cod fritters
+ Pan seared octopus
+ Crispy polenta cake
+ Braised beef short rib
+ Egg tart
+ Dark chocolate cheesecake
+ Rice pudding

The clear winners? Salt cod fritters, pan seared octopus, and egg tarts. Those egg tarts. Yuuummmmm.

Be sure to ask your server for the recommended cocktail/cocktail of the day! In true Portuguese fashion, they serve up some delicious libations to accompany your meal.
author: Yvonne K.

description:
We went on date night and we really enjoyed he food
The restaurant is too loud, people speaking voices and not music
Food is great
Sardine appetizers are great
The cod main dishes are all great
author: Jad A.

description:
Local Noe Valley gem.

Food was good.  Nothing totally stood out to me though.  Oh the whole fish maybe (it was a special that night). Chicken was ok, but nothing to write home about.

The chips and spicy sauce was good.

It's pretty loud inside so if you want quiet intimate date spot, this isn't it.

Loved the Portuguese custard tart for dessert.  When it came out I was so disappointed because it was just this plain tart on a tiny little plate.  But oh when I bit into it it was soooooooo good.  And just enough (for one person).
author: Traci H.

description:
Food: 4/5
Service: 4/5
Ambiance: 4/5
Overall: tasty and rich in flavor. One of the few Portuguese places I've been to in the city and I come back.

The extended review...

Food:

Caldo verde - a very rich, hearty, and tasty soup. For this reason the portion is a little bit smaller but

Camarao cozido - The shrimp is very tasty and the aioli complemented the shrimp perfectly.

Salada de Mariscos - though I only ate the shrimp and fish it was a fairly good dish with a lot of variety.

Ervilhas com chourico - it was an interesting dish which emulated a tartare dish.  Lamb and egg on top of some bread.  Not too shabby.

Carne a jardineria - not bad for a short rib.  Usually I don't order them because they are too bland.  Not a bad effort here as there was some taste in it.

Service: friendly and attentive service.

Ambiance: a nice rustic place and spacious in seating.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. Earlier this year, friends and I made our way to Lisbon where we had some amazing seafood. This was not it. This was more like Spanish tapas than Portuguese food. 

With a party of 6 and reservations they sat us in the backroom which was kind cool but no natural light. :-/ The food was good but nothing amazing and the prices were a little too high for me. 

No dishes wow-ed us. The Portuguese egg tarts were okay - not terrible but nothing like they were in Lisboa. 

By all means, this place isn't bad - I just don't need to go back.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Lots of potential here. Great space, lively ambiance and a solid menu, but the execution of the food was disappointing. I really wanted to like the dishes but most everything was heavy with salt. Maybe Portuguese food is supposed to be that salty, or maybe I just came on a bad day, but I unfortunately wasn't impressed enough for a return visit. The restaurant does get very busy so I'd recommend making reservations if you plan on visiting.

The menu has appetizers, small plates and large plates and is meant to be shared. For 4 people, our waiter suggested ordering about 3 appetizers and 2 large entrees. The only thing I'd recommend from the main menu is the Polvo Na Chapa (octopus). I found everything else to be anywhere from a little salty to very, very salty.

/ / /  PETISCOS / SNACKS  / / /
* PASTEIS DE BACALHAU ($10 for 4 pcs) - 3/5
[salt cod fritters, cilantro mayo]
These were just okay. Decently sized, and soft and moist on the inside, but I was hoping the outside would be crispier. A little too salty for my liking, but better with the salsa they had provided with the chips at the start of our meal.

* SARDINHAS ASADAS ($14 for 3 pcs) - 3.5/5
[grilled monterey sardines, caramelized onion, egg]
The sardines were large and meaty and had a nice grill to them, but otherwise also a little on the salty side and lacking any other flavor. The caramelized onion helped balance out the salt for the most part, but even some parts of the onion had a heavy dose of salt.

/ / /  PRATOS PEQUENOS / SMALL PLATES  / / /
* POLVO NA CHAPA ($18) - 4/5
[pan seared octopus, fennel-bean puree, roasted cauliflower, green beans, pickled gypsy peppers]
Only had 3 pieces of octopus, which made it hard to share between 4 people. This was my highlight of the main meal only because it wasn't salty, but it still wasn't very memorable. The texture of the octopus was okay - not chewy but also not the most tender.

/ / /  PRATOS GRANDES / LARGE PLATES  / / /
* CARNE DE PORCO À ALENTEJANA ($24) - 3.5/5
[braised pork, clams, linguiça, tomato-wine sauce, fingerling potatoes, cilantro]
Large cut of pork but it was on the dry side and needed a lot of sauce, but the tomato-wine sauce, like everything else, was a little too salty

* CARNE A JARDINEIRA ($28) - 3/5
[braised beef short rib, marble potatoes, green beans, english peas, carrots, herbs]
Looked really good but was very disappointing. The short rib was tough and dry and the sauce it was braised in was incredibly salty.

/ / /  SOBREMESAS / DESSERT  / / /
* LEITE DE CREME ($9) - 4.5/5
[cinnamon mousse, seasonal berries, almond brittle]
Creamy and not too rich. Cinnamon flavor was light but definitely there. The almond brittle would have been better for texture if it had more almond but it was mostly just candy and very sticky.
author: Jessie L.

description:
How often do you go to a place where the apps are amazing, but entrees are only ok (or vice versa)?  At Uma Casa, every single dish was delicious and on point!!  I've already asked that we return for my birthday because I find it's so rare for a restaurant to deliver outstanding dish after outstanding dish.  Also, the restaurant is gorgeous, while our server was very attentive and knowledgeable about each dish.  


Below is the FOOD ORDER for 6 people, which was just the right amount

Salt cod fritters [1]- Similar to crab cakes with very good fish-to-breading ratio

House Bread [2] - There were 2 types of bread, one was corn and another was a traditional Portuguese bread.  I personally liked the oil spread

Gambas [2] - Definitely had a kick!  Omg sopping up the extra sauce with the bread was sooo good!

Octopus [1] - Only came with 3 pieces, but only 4 of us ate it.  We made the mistake of eating the gambas first so the spicy taste overwhelmed the octopus, which unfortunately means I can't comment on the flavor.  I can say that the texture was good, not rubbery at all.  Lesson learned....next time, eat the less spicy seafood first.

Halibut [1] - YUM!! We also ordered the braised short ribs, which you'd expect would overwhelm the halibut....but this fish stood its ground.  I actually want to come back for the halibut.  The sauce was excellent, and the fish was the right amount of flakiness.  

Red wine braised short ribs [2] - Perfection.  The meat was cooked just right, and it pretty much fell apart when you touched it with your fork (but in a good way).

Both the Halibut and Braised Short Ribs came on a bed of veggies, which were really fresh and cooked well.  Those were gobbled up too.


So... this sounds like a lot of food, right?  And you'd think we'd all be rolling off our chairs in a food coma at this point.  Oh no, we stepped up and ordered 4 DESSERTS.  The apps/entrees weren't huge, and we shared family-style which I think is the only way to get the most out of eating at Uma Casa.  So near the end, we all had room for a little bit of sweet.  

Definitely come here!!
author: Elle W.

description: Great Portuguese food for a great price! Their bacalhau and bolinho de bacalhau are perfect! I also loved their Caldo Verde.  I just wish they had a little more variety on their menu and I would be back more often.
author: Cristiane B.

description:
What a wonderful dinner! I remember coming here when this was an Italian restaurant, and it was a nice surprise to end up in a familiar space that's been overhauled. The decor is brighter and feels more Mediterranean, just like the food!

RESERVATIONS: Made just one week in advance for dinner for four at 6pm on a Saturday. 

SERVICE: Great! Our server was friendly, funny, and gave good recommendations. 

MUST-HAVES: Savage Islands cocktail, Salda de Tomate (for super fresh ingredients), Octopus, & Pastel de Nata (custard tart).

COCKTAILS
* Savage Islands ($10) - 4 stars
Great! Tropical, well balanced, nice & tart

PETISCOS
* Rissois de camarao (shrimp turnovers $9) - 3.5 stars
Nice crisp, filling more soggy than I expected.

SOPAS E SALADAS
* Salada de Tomate ($12) - 4.5 stars
Absolutely delicious, super fresh ingredients. Love the nectarine. 

PRATOS PEQUENOS
* Milho Frito (crispy polenta cake) - 3.5 stars
Good crisp, otherwise not super memorable. The mushroom flavor was a bit overwhelming.

MARISCOS
* Octopus - 4.5 stars
Simple, delicious! It's so hard to get the texture right but they nailed it.

PRATOS GRANDES
* Carne a Jardineira (braised beef short rib, $28) - 4 stars
Very soft, tasty meat. Bed of veggies very simple. 

* Caldeirada (seafood broth, $29) - 4 stars
I didn't get this dish, but my boyfriend enjoyed it! 

SOBREMESAS
* Pudim Nao Sei (dark chocolate cheesecake, $10) - 3.5 stars
Though I love dark chocolate, This was quite bitter and dry! The caramelized pineapple was a good contrast.

* Pastel de Nata (custard tart, $4) - 4.5 stars
Very delicious, lovely silky texture. Be warned, it's very sweet!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
A lovely spot for dinner in the Noe Valley neighborhood of San Francisco. Uma Casa isn't the type of place I would recommend if you're in a hurry, but if you're looking for a slow leisurely dinner with delicious food and wine, then this is the place for you!

I came here with 2 other friends on a Thursday evening. We made reservations two days in advance through the Uma Casa website and there were still plenty of times available. We arrived a little before our reservation time and was immediately seated since our table was ready.

Our server David was very helpful in providing suggestions on their popular dishes and what to order. None of us were super hungry, so we ordered only a couple items to share:

Pasteis bacalhau ($10): salt cod fritters. These were good but saltier than I was expecting. I wish there was something to eat them with, like rice or bread

Salada de atum ($16): raw yellowfin tuna with quail egg and onion puree. I liked this dish, the yellowfin tuna was very fresh and went well with the complimentary potato chips

Polvo na Chapa ($18): grilled octopus served with a selection of vegetables. My favorite dish from the night as the octopus was unbelievably flavorful and tender. I wanted more!

Carne de Porco a Alentejana ($24): braised pork and clams in a tomato-wine sauce. This dish fell flat for me a little bit, as the braised pork was a little tough and dry. My favorite part of the dish was the clams and also the thick slices of bread served with the dish. It was great dipping the bread into the tomato-wine sauce.

Olive oil and lemon cake ($10): we ordered this because I was curious about the use of olive oil in the cake, but (luckily?) I couldn't really taste it over the lemon flavor. The cake was served in a couple of separate pieces and plated very colorfully with breaks and flower petals. It was just sweet enough to satisfy my sweet tooth without being too sweet; and I thought the firmness was perfect as well.

More so than the food, what I really loved about Uma Casa was the service. Our server David stopped to check in on us every so often but never too frequently to be annoying. He always seemed to have an eye on our wine glasses and would be right there to inquire about another glass. The restaurant was completely full at one point with some people waiting at the door, but we never felt rushed to make room for other diners, and were able to take our time catching up over the course of a long 2.5 hour dinner.

I'm not sure if the kitchen was extremely busy that day and running behind, but our food came out at a slower pace than I am used to. Of course, we were all completely okay with this as it allowed us to take our time and enjoy the food while still catching up.

I took muni here from downtown, but in this area parking is all street. I can usually find parking in Noe Valley pretty easily.

We ended up paying about $65 pp after tax and tip since we had some drinks with dinner as well.
author: Dianna H.

description:
Vegetarians - In main course dont miss the polenta ...you will regret not trying it !


 in desserts dive into the traditional pastel de nata and creme de maracuja!
author: Priyanka L.

description:
Probably no better place for Portuguese in SF. Great drinks, authentic and flavorful food, and fun ambience.

Made a rezzo for 5:30pm on a Saturday. We were one of the first tables seated, though by the time we finished around 6:30 it was a full house. We ordered the warm olives, house bread, and shrimp turnovers to start. Skip the olives unless you're an olive fanatic, they came out a bit mushy. The bread was good, interesting that it was served with olive and chorizo butter. The shrimp turnovers were outstanding.

We also had the baby gem lettuce salad, gulf shrimp, and octopus. The salad and octopus were excellent. Octopus easily the top 3 I've had in SF. The gulf shrimp was a bit different than I expected, a bit spicy in a tomato based sauce. The shrimp was cooked perfectly, but the profile flavor was not what I expected.

The decor is bright and the blue and white tile is a beautiful touch. Also a large private room in the back for parties and events.
author: Tim X.

description:
TLDR: Highly recommended! Beautiful decor, good service, and amazing food. I'd definitely come here again the next time I'm in San Francisco! Easy reservation through Resy! Overall rating: A


It was me and my friend's first time trying Portuguese cuisine. Generally, I'm not a seafood fan but they really impressed me here. Everything was superb. They serve each dish as it's ready. Everything was well paced. They don't change your plates between dishes unless you request it. (I needed to do so because the first dish was spicy and I didn't want to alter the following dishes' flavor profiles.) We split a couple dishes. Here's what we got:

-Complementary homemade potato chips with a mild pureed tomato sauce(?): Delicious!

-GAMBAS MOÇAMBIQUE small plate (gulf shrimp, garlic, white wine, olive oil, malagueta): Spicy sauce and the shrimp was perfectly cooked! The sightly charred bread to mop up the sauce was a great touch! A+

-POLVO DOURADO small plate (cornmeal crusted octopus, roasted pepper emulsion, summer squash, corn, watercress salad): The octopus was nice and tender! Very good! Only thing I didn't like was the surprise celery in the side salad. I hate celery. A

-CARNE à JARDINEIRA large plate (braised beef short rib, english peas, carrots, green beans, fingerling potatoes): This was more like a stew. You could tell this was cooked for a long time. The flavors all really melded together for a hearty dish! It could've easily been bland but it really held its own. The short rib was fork tender. A+

-PASTEL de NATA dessert (Portuguese egg custard tart): My first time having the famous Portuguese egg custard tart! I've only had Chinese and Macau egg custard tarts before. This was actually my least favorite version. Online photos show the tops as almost bruleed and a lovely spotted brown. Ours came out pale. When I bit into the tart the custard came spilling out. It tasted undercooked to me. This was the most disappointing part of my meal, which is sad because I love dessert so much! This needs improvement please! B-


My friend got a sherry based cocktail (Adonis) and I got a Portuguese beer (Melo Abreu Especial bottle). Both drinks were just ok. I love that their drinks are Portuguese! Very authentic! There are no prices on their online menus annoyingly. FYI we paid a total of about $95.00 (before tip) for 2 small plates, 1 large plate, 2 alcoholic drinks, and 1 dessert. This is great for a nice romantic/slightly higher end dinner than your everyday restaurant. I miss this restaurant now that I'm home in NYC. Hopefully, Uma Casa will be around for a long time so I can return here in the future!
author: D D.

description: Amazing place to eat, my friends and I had a blast. They speak Spanish, Portuguese and English. Imagine
author: Madgscherly S.

description:
UMA CASA
Cuisine:Portuguese 
Atmosphere: decorated warm; setting like you were in Portugal itself.
Service: Courteous
Food: Traditional but some items lacked flavor or found to be dry.

Food portions can be shared; my favorite items were the Shrimp turn overs, House made bread with delicious chourico butter & olive butter; and Caldierada. 

Don't get me wrong the food was mediocre and improvement can be made. 
But the service and company made it enjoyable. 

Thank you Uma Casa!
author: Kathy V.

description:
My husband and I fell in live with Uma Casa shortly after our visit to Portugal and when we thought we might be moving to the neighborhood of Noe Valley. (We instead opted for the Sunset, which I am overjoyed about.) 

The food is amazing! Our first time we sat at the bar, and I recall service being a bit brazen. The second time was a larger affair with my extended family, was daytime/brunch and an all-together much warmer experience in the dining room. 

Standouts were: shrimp turnovers (béchamel, piri-piri aioli) and poached head-on shrimp (lemon aioli). I recall my father and husband duking it out for a vegetarian frittata dish. 

Five stars for the food.
author: Camille L.

description: First and foremost, the food was excellent. What is driving my less than stellar review is the service. It started out good, then half way through the meal we almost became an afterthought to the server's larger surrounding tables. It took 15-20 minutes for our entree to come out after our small plate was consumed. We waited an additional length of time for our entree and finally our dessert plates to be cleared. After the completion of our meal, we waited for 10 minutes until he finally dropped off our check and then never bothered to pick it up even though he walked by three times. I eventually had to give it to the host who gave it to the wrong server to ring up. Our server eventually came back only to drop the check off again! Obviously, he was not paying attention. We finally got our check after a 20 minute ordeal. I commented to the host when we left that the food was amazing, but the service was horrible. I'd come back for the food, but would definitely avoid the server.
author: Kristopher D.

description:
Allegedly the first and only Portuguese restaurant in town. I had been back for a day and half from a timezone that is 15 hours ahead of here, thus my comprehension of food and time were a little mixed up. However, I knew one thing - I wanted a cool place for a meal. I wanted something not Asian because I go to Asia on a regular basis now for work. 

Funny enough, Uma Casa means Grandma's House in Portuguese and one of my new favorite restaurants (not the one by the West Lake but near my hotel) in Hangzhou is called Grandma's House and it had the best begger's chicken. So I knew whatever it had, not going to get chicken. 

Short ribs was a much safer bet. Really wanted a salad after a week of no salad (can't trust such things even though it's probably okay in Asia), so the arugula salad came to the rescue. Had also the pickled veggies. Then the shrimp. All very good.  Dessert has a few things that seemed decent and we had the berries pie.

All in all, a decent meal. It's not Fernando's, which is a beach front restaurant in Macau, and it's not Europe, this to me is a very Americanized version of it, and for what it is worth, the price is very reasonable and the food very good. For quiet Noe, this spot was hopping. 

Glad that I was able to check off this April edition hottest restaurant list. So good to finally have a Portuguese place to serve the ever so demanding, food culture centric society that is called San Francisco.
author: Victoria E.

description:
The food at this restaurant was delicious, and the decor was really nice. The service, however, was atrocious.

Upon arrival, the hostess told us that they gave away our table because we were one minute late, and we would have to wait 30 minutes because they have a policy of double booking their tables.

We inquired about sitting at another table that was available, and she had to check with her manager to ensure that was acceptable.

I got angry, and said that their policy was "f***ing rude and inconsiderate." The owner then came to our table to say how rude we were, and how i shouldn't have accosted their young female hostess.

I didn't understand why the age or gender of the hostess mattered, but we tried to explain to him that telling a party they lost their table because they were one minute late was extremely rude, and no other restaurant would ever do that.

He said every restaurant does that, and wouldn't listen to reason or even allow us to speak, constantly interrupting us. 

We decided to stay, and had a great meal (the waiter was really nice), but the owner was such a jerk, it cast a dark pallor over our meal. 

So, I wouldn't return (now would anyone in my party, and previously, they were regulars there). I strongly recommend to anyone who values professionalism and courtesy to avoid this restaurant, until they get their act together.
author: rick j.

description: Food was probably more like a 3.5, but had a pleasant time so will bump them up to a 4! Definitely more of a European vibe, as the wait was a bit long even though the place was empty. We stood at the front for awhile without any direction before a hostess came. No big deal, service was still really friendly! We ordered the salt cod fritters, the cauliflower soup, the octopus, and the ribeye. Our waitress recommended that we order 3-5 dishes, but we ended up ordering way too much! The cod fritters were pretty good! Super salty- but it was not dense and potato-y like I thought it would be. It was in fact mostly shredded fish inside. A good fried crisp on the outside. Defitely would skip the cauliflower puree- this had no flavor to me, other than a bit sour. The octopus was delicious! The cornmeal batter is super light so you can mostly taste the tender octopus and the salad that it came with as very refeshing with the corn and squash. The ribeye was ok, but we were so full by then we could barely eat any. It was a bit too charred for me, but the leftovers the next day were good. Overall- a fun place to dine, food is not bad. Might return with more friends and if I was in the mood for Portuguese.
author: Vivian D.

description:
I'm not familiar with Portuguese food so I didn't know what to expect. For the most part, every dishes that I had here were pretty good.

We started with the salt cod fritters. I enjoyed this dish. It was fried nicely and it had a nice texture (soft on the inside crispy on the outside). I thought the mayonnaise that came with it could use some acid or it needed some kick.

Next we had the gambas (aka shrimp). This dish was pretty good as well. It had a bold onion, garlic flavor, and it was pretty spicy, not sure what type of peppers they used but I liked it! The dish came with some grilled bread to soak up the sauce.

Our next dish was the grilled chicken wings with piri piri spices. They were grilled to perfection. Nice charred flavor, and the piri piri spices were tasty. It wasn't that spicy.

For our main courses, we had the pan roasted sea bass and the braised pork with clams. The sea bass dish was just okay. I think the fish was slightly over cooked although I really liked the condiments that came with it: some dices tomatoes and red onion salsa with some sautéed greens and garbanzo beans. It was simple and light. The pork dish was okay too. Pork was tender (pretty lean), the clams tasted fresh, and the sauce was delicious. 

Desserts were just okay so not worth mentioning them.

Overall I had enjoyed my first Portuguese dining experience although I didn't have anything that blew me away. Service was friendly and attentive, and that's why I decided to give this place four stars. I would go back for the salt cod fritters, the gambas, and the chicken wings and sit at the bar.
author: Sam M.

description:
Went here for a date night on a Tuesday. We both got the tasting menu, which had so much food it was much more than just a taste! It was a great deal for amazing cuisine. $33 per person for a 3 course meal at a nice restaurant in SF? Unheard of. And my partner got the $25 wine pairings that came with 3 generously-poured glasses--less than $10 per glass for good wine in SF? Also unheard of. 

Highlights: cod and potato puffs, caldo, piri piri chicken, and custard tart, our fantastic waitress  

To top it off, the Chef and owner came out to greet the patrons. We recognized him because we saw him on Chopped (that's how we found out about Uma Casa in the first place). He was super friendly and gracious. Really enjoyed meeting him. 

Highly highly recommend this place for the gorgeous decor, comfortable ambience, top-notch service, incredible food, and affordable prices.
author: Sara G.

description: My husband and I went to Uma Casa with friends last night and had a wonderful time.  One of the friends who dined with us recommended Uma Casa as he has eaten there before and knows the chef.  The decor is pleasant and the restaurant was busy on a Sunday evening.  We ordered a variety of dishes to enjoy family style.  The presentation was beautiful and flavors were delicious. We had the cod fritters for an appetizer and fish of the day, pork riblets, bacalau, chicken and polenta.  Our server was pleasant and attentive and I would definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone who enjoys Portuguese food or just wants to try something different.  They even brought me a dessert and sang Happy Birthday to me even though it wasn't necessarily a birthday dinner.
author: Nancy B.

description:
I couldn't be more grateful for Uma Casa being in my neighborhood.  Even if it wasn't I'd drive 500 miles for the food. Portuguese restaurants are so hard to find as it is, and how lucky I found this gem.  

We started with the PASTEIS DE BACALHAU -salt cod fritters, cilantro mayo. First time trying them & I would eat them every day - if I could.  

We shared the ARROZ DE MARISCO - a classic food of Chef Telmo's childhood & if this is the real deal then I'm booking a trip to Portugal.

We ordered 
MILHO FRITO - crispy polenta cake, kale, madeira braised mushrooms, frisee.  My dream vegetarian dish - even the meat eaters in our group loved it!

The flavors of the food - especially seafood - is so bold yet bright and combinations of seasoning and spices that was so unique & delicious. I would trust the chef unconditionally with anything on the menu.  There are no misses here, they nail everything in the best possible way.

The service was outstanding. Not too much, not too little - just the right amount of attention. Our server was very patient as we had a lot of questions about the menu items and preparation as this was our first time eating Portuguese cuisine.

The chef (Telmo) came out from the kitchen and stopped by every table to greet and chat with the diners. This is where Uma Casa is a standout as you rarely have that personalized interaction with a chef.  It highlights how much he cares about the customers experience and wants you to tell him the good, bad & ugly.  

At Uma Casa it's all goodness!
author: KEL C.

description:
Hard to get table with NO reservation on weekend night. 
Beautiful new restaurant in a Noe Valley SF district. Cocktails were really good. Deserts are delicious too. It's a good place for local Noe Valley residents to have a dinner
author: Svetlana K.

description: A new neighborhood gem in Noe valley! Food was pretty good!. We got the special which was a whole fish, had an amazing tenderness with a variety of flavors , $35. The chicken was just okay, I've had better and probably wouldn't recommend it to others, $25. I would defiantly come back, but make sure to order the right stuff. The ambiance is nice and makes a good date spot! Parking is also relatively easy to find! Service was okay, it could've been better.
author: Sumbal A.

description:
Enjoyed my experience here! The decor is lovely and relaxing: it's Mediterranean feeling, in a way that's airy and cozy at the same time. This makes the ambience versatile, in that it's suitable for a casual dinner with friends or a date. 

As far as the food, everything was delicious! You can order small plates to share with your table, or they have a good selection of entrées that can be their own meal as well. 

The standout item we got was the salt cod fritter appetizer, which was decadent and delicious. I also really enjoyed the linguado; the halibut was cooked perfectly and the dish was presented beautifully! The pasteis de nata dessert was also yummy, although the crust was more dense than the version I had in Portugal. 

Prices were on the higher side, but okay for the quality of the food. Excited to have a place like this in the neighborhood!
author: Christine G.

description:
Nothing like a neighborhood restaurant to make you feel at home.  I don't travel much out of the country so I can't speak to the authenticity, but I can tell you that the food here was on point.  My husband and I dropped in for a late date night and were able to get seated at the bar.  We quickly were given their homemade chips with a dipping sauce that was already told us dinner was going to be amazing.  From there we had the salt cod fritters, a couple of oysters, and fried asparagus.  All were delicious.  For protein we had the gambas mocambique and alcatra short ribs.  I loved all the flavors and textures, and the shared plates made it a fun night for both of us.  Dessert was the only thing I was just ok with.  The olive oil cake was good, but the citrus sauce seemed a bit off for some reason. The service was well executed and very friendly.  

I'm always glad with my better half tells me to remember a restaurant when we can't think of any where to go.  Uma Casa will definitely be one of those places to keep in our dining out rotation.
author: Maria S.

description:
Food: enjoyed the cod fritters, sardines (really large sardines, could have shared one between two people), octopus, shrimp, seafood risotto, short rib (although a bit heavy for my taste). The desserts were probably the best part of the meal. The custard tart and cheesecake were to die for (both not too sweet which is exactly how I like my desserts).

Drinks: Had the WTP to start which was good. Then a bottle of Albarinho with our food (really good). The madeira dessert wine was the best (ports were a bit to sweet).

Service: Liz was great

Ambiance: Good all around

Solid place for group dinners or date night.
author: Laura D.

description:
Uma Casa makes you feel like you stepped into a restaurant in Portugal.

I was really impressed by the decor, and the beautiful open space. The service was also great; our waitress took good care of us, and was quick and thorough the whole night.

I had the grilled octopus as an appetizer, which was so fresh and light and for dinner I had the "alcatra" which is the short rib. The meat itself was so mouthwatering and the potato puree was so smooth and delicious that I didn't want to share.

I did have a problem with the Portugese cream tarts which were super dry and super hard. I'm sure a lot of customers look forward to the famous tarts and for them to be fresh and creamy is a must!
author: Zarene S.

description:
Very good home style Portuguese food. Friendly service, good energy. Prices were reasonable (though higher than the menu on their website).They let us enjoy a nice, leisurely dinner (felt via European compared to so many US places that are all about turning the tables). 

DRINKS
Low groan cocktail- vermut/amontillado/americano- was a nice riff on a negroni

PETISCOS (snacks)
Sadly they were out of the sardines, but pickled veggies ($6) were nice and crisp. I'm not a fan of fried anything, but everyone else liked the cod fitters ($10).

SALADA/SOPES
Loved the arugula salad ($12) with fruit, nuts, and cheese. Generous size was good for sharing. Caldo verde was a heavy broth with potatoes and sausage. Not my fave, but brother said it was as good as he has from his native friends.

PRATOS PEQUENOS (small plates)
Loved the shrimp with garlic and white white ($16), served with some crusty bread for dipping in the sauce. 

PRATOS GRANDES (large plates)
Braised short rib ($28) was tender and reminded me of mom's pot roast, served with green beans and potatoes. Grilled octopus ($18) pretty good, too, though I've had better.

DESSERT
The pasteis de nata ($4) are yummy little egg tarts. The chocolate mousse ($10) is more like a ganache on a crust. Pretty good, though very rich.

Overall, pretty good place. Warning- the open kitchen wafts amazing aromas throughout the place all evening, but you'll take them home with you on your clothes. Not sure I'd come back since there are so many other places to try in SF, but definitely recommend if you haven't been. Service is great and very good food.
author: Ryen B.

description:
Food, service, ambience, all excellent. Despite a full house the two wait staff did a great job and the busser was right on cue. We found the food to be as good as, if not better, than we had on a recent trip to Portugal. 

The high ceilings, wood floors, and tiled walls (nice tiles - appear to be from Portugal) tend to make it a bit noisy when it's a full house, but not unbearable. 

The wine cellar looks very interesting. I want to get a closer look next time. Kind of looked like a wine confessional from a distance. No bad wines on the list though, so no need to ask for forgiveness on that count.
author: Joe P.

description:
Half a star. Not sure why this restaurant is rated so highly. The food is extremely salty. It got to the point where my tongue was numb before the end of the meal. The food was not impressive at all. There are some points that go to presentation, and that's the "half" star. Still, I don't care if my food is plated in the ugliest way possible. If it doesn't taste good then why should I eat it? In this case, the salt was so heavy that I ended up not tasting much at all. I did not even want to look at the dessert menu (and I always want dessert). 

I also felt like there may have been some discrimination upon being seated. We (a non-white family) were a group of 5 with a reservation, but were seated at a small table for 4. When we were seated, the restaurant was still fairly empty. I didn't think much of it until I saw another party of 5 (a white family) being sat at a much larger table, about 30m after we arrived. It could have been just my perception. I am in no way saying that the host was explicitly racist, but it seemed strange to seat our party at a table that was obviously too small to fit everyone. 

I will not be returning to this restaurant in the future.
author: Bryan C.

description:
We had a lovely dinner at Uma Casa, the only Portuguese restaurant in SF. I've been excited about this restaurant opening for a while. The space is open and welcoming; the decor is mostly white/beige with some blue accents. It felt relaxing and comfortable.

Our server explained that all the items are meant to be shared and we were concerned that we wouldn't have enough food. We ended up sharing:
-Rissois de camarao: Each order came with two fried shrimp turnovers. I liked them!
-Arroz de pato: Again, it came with two risotto "bricks" and it was perfect for us. There were about 4 pieces of tender duck breast. The red wine reduction paired so well with the meat. Another winner.
-Alcatra: Everyone on Yelp seems to love these short ribs. I've eaten many short ribs in my life and sorry to burst the bubble but these were just ok. It wasn't as tender as some of the others I've had. The accompanying greens and salted meat were just too salty for me. It took away from the rich flavor of of the short rib. I loved the sweet potato puree but the rest of the dish was not as good as I had anticipated.

By this point, we were full but we soldiered on and ordered unnecessary desserts. I had the pasteis de nata. It was served in a bowl/dish that made it very hard to cut into the dessert. A flat plate would've been better. We also ordered the Pear and Almond Tart. It was too sweet for me.

The price is very reasonable for SF dining and the food is solid. Just don't expect it to be exceptional.
author: Yi Z.

description: Seriously excellent food and service.  The pre fix menu was an amazing deal and so very good.
author: molly m.

description: After Fat Rice in Chicago, I found myself randomly craving Po'Tarts. Is it random? I mean I grew up with it. Nostalgically craving it might be the better description. We came for dinner for a random date night. Tired of home cooking I suppose (ha ha). Uma Casa is in this really cute neighborhood and the muni runs by here. Not a lot of parking admittedly. The decor in the restaurant is so cozy. Very Mom and Pop reminiscent. They give this tiny bowl of home made chips and spicy sauce as a pre-meal appetizer. We got the 3-meal course as it came with the Portuguese tart, which was a big reason for why we came. It was an awesome choice because it was a good amount of food. I got this seafood soup and the chicken with fries on the side. Totally delicious and worth the price. The best thing was the egg tart at the end. It came with a side of cinnamon if you want to sprinkle atop of it. SO GOOOOOD. And it came warm. Cute place for dinner night!
author: Michelle R.

description:
Excellent representation of modern Portuguese food in a charming atmosphere.

Shrimp turnovers (4/5) - delicious and perfectly crispy. Nice bites

Caldo verde (4.5/5) - an elegant version of this staple Portuguese dish. It wasn't too watery and also not too thick.

Sardines (4.5/5) - expertly grilled and good size 

Octopus (3/5) - good amount of vegetables but there octopus itself was very small portion and not as tender as it could be. The smaller slightly tougher pieces thus lacked much flavor or good consistency

Happy to come back here anytime I'm craving Portuguese food.
author: Victor W.

description:
Had a great time with friends there last night, a Wednesday. Our server was David, he treated us right, and was very knowledgeable about the Portuguese wines, as well (we shared a bottle of the "Foz de Arouce Beiras Baga Beira Atlantico 2012" on his recommendation and it was great).

Here's the stuff we had (uh, yeah, it was a lot of food for the 3 of us, but there weren't any leftovers!!) I was running 30 min late, but my friends had got there on time, and, thankfully, got some awesome food recommendations from the barkeep (thanks, guys!!). Using those as a base, we added a few things of our own, and here's all the stuff we came up with:

AZEITONAS - warm olives, olive oil, lemon, garlic, herb
PÃO COM MANTEIGA - house-made bread, chouriço butter, olive butter
PASTEIS DE BACALHAU - salt cod fritters, cilantro mayo
SARDINHAS ASADAS - grilled monterey sardines, caramelized onion, egg
SALADA DA TERRA - roasted beets, butternut squash, farro, cumin-honey vinaigrette, radish
POLVO NA CHAPA - pan seared octopuses, white bean fennel puree, roasted cauliflower, green beans, pickled gypsy peppers
"SOPAS" - braised beef short rib, bread base, marble potatoes, cabbage, carrots, mint

I also tried the "Low Groan" cocktail (their take on a Negroni) in the beginning of the meal, as well as one of the Madeiras, the Rare Wine Co New York Malmsey, at the end - both were awesome.

Everything was superb, and it was an amazing night out - very much looking forward to the next time I can make it - kudos to the staff & to David!!
author: Jesse E.

description:
Uma Casa is by far the best addition to Noe Valley since we moved here. We came a few weeks ago the day after the opening and were blown away. We didn't think to make a reservation but we were able to snag one of the last spots at the communal table to begin our meal. Neither A nor I had ever had Portuguese food so we didn't really know what to expect. Our waitress was able to make us a few recommendations. We decided to split a snack, a small plate and a large plate. I also ordered a glass of Vinho Verde ($9) which was the perfect compliment to the meal. 

We ordered:

-Rissois de Camaro ($8) - This was our "snack" and were described to us as Shrimp Turnovers. They were scrumptious. Honestly. I could have had 3 of these plates for dinner and been content. Very satisfying.

-Codorniz Vinho De Alhos ($15) - This was our small plate and it was AWESOME. We wanted to order the Arroz de Pato but they were out and honestly, I am happy we had the chance to order this. I normally do not love fried food but this was delightful. I wish they served this in a bigger plate portion because I would be all over it.

-Alcatra ($26)-This was our main and was delicious. Very hearty. Great flavors. Would order again and would recommend.

Our waitress misheard our order initially so we were brought the Caldeirada ($28) as well. Once she realized the mistake, she generously left it for us to try while they prepared the Alcatra and removed it from our bill. We were really happy we got to sample this as well. If you're into seafood, this dish is meant for you. Neither A nor I eat a TON of fish so this may have been our least favorite.

There were a few hiccups in service while we were there but that is to be expected since they are so new. It seemed like the runners did not know which table was which but usually, it was close enough that the party who ordered the food could figure out it was theirs. Our waitress also dropped the free chips and sauce when she was bumped into but she took it in stride and didn't even let out a single curse. I know I would have :) I cannot wait to come back. This place is amazing and honestly, a place that is worth traveling to even if you're not in the Noe/Mission/Bernal Heights area. It was a real treat.
author: Carrie W.

description:
3.5 STARS

Every time I Yelp an ethnic restaurant, I always look for reviews from natives. You know, the "I'm Chinese so I know what good Chinese food is...Fat Kok has the best and most authentic egg rolls ever!" Hmmm, except Chinese people don't really eat egg rolls. I'm 3/4ths Chinese so I know 75% of the time of what good Chinese food is. I'm kidding, I don't but I can appreciate a good egg roll. 

Uma Casa is the first Portuguese restaurant in San Francisco that opened in the former Incanto/Porcellino space, and we visited on the third opening night. The closest I've come to Portuguese food in the city is faceplanting into a bowl of Caldo Verde Soup at Grubstake...at 2 am. Naturally, I'm going to turn to yelpers who are of Portuguese decent and it was kind of mixed for Uma Casa (granted, there weren't that many). 

The menu is fairly extensive with a lot of seafood options. They have snacks ($5-$21), raw seafood ($3-$15), soups & salads ($9-$12), small plates ($12-$16), large plates ($20-$28), and desserts ($4-$9). Small wine and beer list. Low abv cocktails available. 

Our dinner started out strong but went downhill after our apps. 

We started with the Pastéis de Bacalhau: Salt cod fritters, cilantro mayo ($10): http://bit.ly/2jlk8L8 which were fantastic. The golden brown pouches were wonderfully crisp and filled my lots of minced salt cod (a staple of Portuguese cuisine). Get these! 

The Gambas Mocambique: Gulf shrimp, garlic, white wine, olive oil, malagueta ($14): http://bit.ly/2j9UoCc. The shrimp were huge and perfectly cooked - firm and tender in a robust, garlic wine sauce. The accompanying grilled bread was the perfect vessel for sopping up all the sauce. 

The Codorniz Vinho De Alhos: Fried, marinated quail, squash purée jus, pearl onions, herbs ($15): http://bit.ly/2iW09FZ was a very well balanced dish - savory (sauce) and sweet (squash) with a good punch of acid from the dressed microgreens. However, the quail didn't taste very marinated as it was a bit bland. Also, the quail could have been crisper.  

The highly anticipated Alcatra: Red wine braised short rib, sweet potato, braised greens, gremolata ($27): http://bit.ly/2ivNhTM was utterly disappointing in flavor, texture, and execution. The short rib was very tough, dry, and bland. Seems like there wasn't enough braising liquid and the short ribs weren't cooked long enough to break down the connective tissue. I like collard greens and sweet potatoes but in this dish, they were an unappetizing sour and sweet mush.

I love Pastéis de Nata and grew up eating them (my mom is from Macau). After seeing them at neighboring tables, my friend warned me, "I hope you don't expect them to taste like how they're supposed to!" Maaaan, why you gotta say that? Well, my friend was right. The Portuguese Egg Tart's ($4) non-flaky crust was really oily and there was a super thin layer of cloyingly sweet custard: http://bit.ly/2iaErNq. So disappointing that it made me want to drive to 85°C Bakery afterwards. 

As for drinks, usually low abv cocktails can either taste like cough syrup or taste super bitter but I decided to try one any way (in hopes that I'll find the unicorn of low abv cocktails). The WPT ($10) tasted like a sweet carbonated sangria: http://bit.ly/2jv88uH. Unfortunately, I could only manage several sips because it was too sweet. My friend ordered a glass of wine that went undrunk. 

I'm very understanding and patient when it comes to grand openings but I felt like we were being rushed out of there. We weren't even there for an hour, when our bill was plopped on our table without asking if we wanted anything else like dessert. My friend looked into the waiting area and there was no one was waiting for a table. We had to flag down our server and let him know that we had wanted to try their dessert.

While waiting for our food, we noticed that some tables had some delicious looking chips and dip on their tables (not on the menu), and some didn't. I later found out these were complimentary. I'm not the type who goes to Costco with an expired membership to fill up on all the free samples (if you are, shame on you), nor am I out for freebies but please be consistent. Every table should get the complimentary snack, yea?

The busboy and food runner were super nice though so kudos to them. 

The former Incanto/Porcellino space has been brightened up with royal blue walls and beautiful rustic tiles. I like how they added a seafood station in the bar area. Unless you go on a weekday or have a 5 pm dinner, I don't recommend it for a quiet date. There was no sound dampening - with the loud music and nearly packed restaurant, it was deafening. I had to read my friend's lips and shout across the table. 

Parking is relatively easy in the area. 

Go to Uma Casa for the snacks and small plates, that is all. Oh, and bring a bottle of wine with you. Saúde!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Very loud and lively restaurant.  The food was a solid 3.  We had:
- Salt cod fritters (3/5)
- Potato soup (3/5)
- Gambas Mozambique (4/5) - Good shrimp, and it came with bread to soak up the excellent sauce.
- Short ribs (3/5) - Tastes like pot roast.  The meat was on top of a tasty bed of bread that soaked up the sauce.

The portion sizes were pretty big, as we had half the short ribs left over between the two of us.

Our waiter was friendly and knowledgeable, but it felt like the place was severely understaffed.  In fact, this place probably had the slowest service of any restaurant I've ever been to in the United States (e.g. 20 minutes to get seated for our reservation, 20 minutes for drinks to arrive after ordering them, 30 minutes between appetizers and entree, 30 minutes with our credit card on the table waiting to pay with nobody picking it up).  So minus one star for that.  Thank goodness for good company.  Overall, coming here detracted from our night, unfortunately.  Hopefully there were some extenuating circumstances on this night and others won't experience the same thing.
author: Simon L.

description:
This place is a MUST if you're in town visiting. Everything we ordered was excellent, except for the dessert. Maybe the appetizer and entrees were so good that I had a high expectations.

Highly recommend the Cod Fritters!!!

Food - 5.0
Service - 5.0
Ambiance - 4.5
author: Aaron K.

description:
Came to this place on a Sunday evening for a special dinner with my family.  Four of us, 2 adults and two kids, 7 and 10 yrs old. My kids were dubious since they had never had Portuguese food, but I was interested in seeing what this place had to offer. 

I was greatly impressed by the decor of the restaurant, and how relaxing and homey it feels.  We came around 6:30 pm and were able to be seated immediately without a reservation.  We loved our dishes that had just the right level of the sea flavor.  My kids loved the salt cod fritters. We also ordered the Piri Piri chicken, and the seafood risotto.  My youngest appreciated the kids menu grilled cheese.  I loved the salty goodness of the risotto and all it's underwater creatures that were part of a great dish. My compliments to the chef, the staff and the only Portuguese restaurant in the city.
author: Benji D.

description: Excellent dinner! Celebrated my birthday here tonight. My last job took me to Portugal several times and the food was always amazing. So I was really happy with the menu, even happier with our selection of dishes. We had "Polvo Dourado" (octopus) appetizer - excellent & highly recommended, crispy on outside and tender inside; the "Mariscada" (seafood stew with halibut, scallop, mussels, clams, shrimp, tomato-saffron broth, potatoes, grilled bread) - very good, halibut, shrimp, clams, and broth were my faves; and "Bacalhau Gomes de Sá" (baked salt cod casserole, potatoes, caramelized onion, parsley aioli, crumbled olive, egg) - this is a very traditional dish and executed well. Between the two of us, these three dishes provided a pretty filling meal. So we only had room for a "pastel de nata" for dessert.  We were tempted to have a glass of Porto but we were stuffed! Really wonderful and attentive staff. Unassuming on the outside, beautiful and warm on inside with contemporary furnishings. Reminded me of being back in Portugal. We highly recommend this restaurant tucked away in the neighborhood.
author: Kelly W.

description: Had a great time with friends at Uma Casa. We had a drink at the bar to start where the bartender walked us through the selection of Portuguese wines and aperitifs. Dinner was great. We had the special (whole branzino) which was excellent with a salad, oysters with pari pari hot sauce, and the short rib. Interior decoration makes you feel like you are in a hip part of Porto or Lisbon. Will definitely be back
author: Shane C.

description:
Uma Casa was overall delicious, and had a very nice ambience. 

What we ordered (for 2 people): 
Vinho verde - a bottle for the table. It was the most affordable bottle on the menu. Understandably so - it was light but I wasn't blown away by the flavor. 
Cod fritters - excellent! There were four fried cod fritters placed on some green (cilantro?) mayo. There was a lot of cod inside the fried batter, which was awesome. 
Sardines - a little bit less impressed with this dish. There were three pieces of sardines (and they were pretty big) but there was nothing particularly outstanding. Watch out for the little fish bones! We spent a lot of time picking the fish from the bone. I liked the very thinly sliced eggs. 
Gamba (shrimp + bread) - the shrimp were plump and juicy! And the bread was very fluffy and chewy. You can dip the bread into the tomato sauce, which had a spicy kick to it. Very good dish. 
Seafood risotto - I loved the arborio rice. It was cooked just so that it wasn't too soft, and it still had a little bite to it. The seafood in it was excellent as well - some squid, clams... but the saffron rice was the star of this dish. 
Portuguese tarts - very underwhelmed. They tasted soggy, and the crust was not flaky at all. The top was also not caramelized. They were still yummy, but only if they were not advertised as Portuguese tarts.
author: Julianna K.

description:
4.5 stars rounded up

One second through the glass doors of Uma Casa & we already felt that the vibe was right; there are shrimp on ice at the front counter, there's chatter from every table, & a romantic glow radiates over the entire space. 

The verdict was clear after sampling just two or three items -- that returning to this restaurant takes precedence over trying someplace new. 

We tried: 
-- salted watermelon was the homemade soda flavor of the evening: an infinite amount of stars for a pretty pink sweet & salty drink that packs a flavor wallop. 
-- complimentary chips & a spicy peri peri sauce: can I have an extra large portion to take to my bed whilst I binge-watch my shows? 
-- elote: delicious, as to be expected 
-- gambas moçambique: shrimp with amazing garlic & white wine 
-- acatra: red wine braised short ribs, which tasted sweeter than we would've preferred. Will try the sea bass next time 
-- dessert: dark chocolate cheesecake, & peach & blackberry tart... neither spectacular, 3.75 stars for the sweets. 

Try this Church Street restaurant; it's a Portuguese vacation for your taste buds.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Wow. Nearly perfect first meal there last night. 

Started with the arugula and shaved cheese salad, really well balanced, simple salad.  Next we shared the shrimp turnovers appetizer filled with molten béchamel and a spicy aioli and they were beyond delicious, just such a incredible blend of rich flavors without ever being greasy or overwhelming.  For our small plate, we had the grilled octopus and this is a must try, perfectly cooked and accented with some savory veggies.  Last but definitely not least, we ended with the salt cod casserole, probably the best version of that dish I've ever had. Rare that every single dish was a hit but that was the happy case here.

Service was friendly and well paced.  Ambience was energetic but warm.

Highly recommended.
author: Saminda W.

description: I was so hopeful for this restaurant as my husband and I had just returned from Portugal and each plate we had we were unimpressed.  I was so hopeful for the Pastel de Nata and that failed too.  From a $44 small pitcher of Sangria, to a poorly made dessert; to mediocre service - I will not be going back.  At these prices you only get once chance.
author: diane n.

description: Uma Casa is the best Portuguese restaurant in San Francisco. I like going there for the food but also for the drink menu. If you haven't checked them out and you like Portuguese food, I recommend you doing so as you're truly missing out on a gem of a place. Uma Casa is like Cristiano Ronaldo, it's no joke. A few menu items that I have had in more than an occasion and I have been impressed with are Caldo Verde Soup, Camarao Cozido and the Carne a jardineria. I really enjoy the caldo verde every time I go there -- it's probably my favorite entree. It's flavorful and rich in texture and worth every spoon! If I am in a great mood for dessert, I also get their dark chocolate cheesecake! It's divine! Do not wait any longer and come try this European adventure!
author: Marissa J.

description:
You have to love a restaurant that's in a neighborhood where the parking is easy. That starts things off well. Add to that friendly and attentive service and things are looking good.  Also, excellent Portuguese wine. 

There were four of us eating, so the 4 stars is the result of mostly positive reviews. 

We started with the sardines ( sardinhas asadas) which were tasty, easy to fillet and light.  The tomato salad was good and the bread was tasty ( but $6 for a fairly small portion). The complimentary chips were fresh and hot - but such a tiny bowl!!  

We had the sea bass ( robala), the (Frango Churrasco) grilled chicken served with fries and greens - very good, and the Caldeirada - sea bass, shrimp, mussels, etc. The latter was a hit with the two who ordered it. 

Desserts were good not great - rice pudding, fruit tart and chocolate mousse. 

Final verdict - 3 out of of 4 will be back!
author: Karne N.

description: I came here for restaurant week and was a little underwhelmed with the food. I have had great experiences with restaurant week but nothing on the menu really blew me away. I was looking forward to the custard dessert and was disappointed with the taste. I enjoyed the ambiance and its a nice place to take a date but the food was just okay.
author: Shristi R.

description:
Very underwhelming--coming from someone who's been to Portugal twice, I would hardly call the food here authentic. If you've never had Portuguese food and would like to try, this might be an ok place to go if you have the $$ to spend on average food.

Appetizers were ok--I was actually a bit offended at the toasted sliced white bread, the least you could've done is get some sort of baguette or Portuguese rolls. The massa malagueta (hot pepper paste) was ok, but was served with your regular good ol' American potato chips???? When normally it's served with cheese & bread in Portugal. And there was pickled carrots & onions? Not like Portuguese cuisine at all.

Caldo verde (green soup with chorizo) was meh, a bit too salty and the chorizo was cooked in a way that was too soft, and tasted a bit strange, not like chorizo at all. I make this soup on a regular basis and I very much prefer my own version.

Entrees were a bit better. I got the arugula salad and my boyfriend who's Portuguese got the Frango churrasco (grilled chicken) which was pretty good as well. 

Pastel de Nata (Portuguese egg tart) was just ok; the crust was too thick and chewy, not crispy like the authentic ones.

Overall I suspect some of the food has been somewhat changed / catered to American taste buds--but why would you do that? Wouldn't recommend.
author: Shen G.

description:
I didn't feel the dishes were authentic and the service was a bit disorganized, but our server was very friendly, although I really dislike that restaurants don't check in with you as you get your dishes.  The place is pretty noisy, chairs are not very comfortable, lately that seems to be the trend.  

We decided to order a bunch of dishes to share and asked the server to make sure the pace was not too fast and that the pairings make sense, since he mentioned that they come out as they are ready. 

The salt cod croquets were nice, crispy, great flavor, definitely taste the saltiness.

The beet and other roots salad was beautiful but bland, had absolutely no flavor and the beets were not sweet.  Some acidity or citrus would have been a nice touch. 

It took a while for our sardines to come out, the waiter said he would take them off the bill.   Frankly I liked the break and didn't see an issue with timing. The sardines lacked some flavor, lemon would be nice, maybe even some crostini a little garlic. 

Then the duck and risotto cakes came out.  No one cleaned our dishes, I was not a fan of eating meat on a dish that just had sardines on it.  The dish was a total miss, the risotto cakes were huge, the duck was more like lunch meat than breast meat, it was totally dry and not what I imagined.  There wasn't much sauce either, total miss.

We also ordered the shrimp but they forgot to bring them and we were full at this time so decided to skip them.

All and all, not impressed with the dishes or service.
author: Inga W.

description:
Disclaimer that I went here for restaurant week, not a normal night.

Uma Casa was very underwhelming. The food was bland and the service was terrible. Each item ordered took an exceedingly long time. I had the pork shoulder off the restaurant week menu; it was dry and flavorless. For the price, I definitely wouldn't recommend going here. I won't be back.
author: Joshua B.

description: This is my second time here. I enjoy the experience that the restaurant provides. I'm Portuguese and live in a very Portuguese household. Therefore, I eat Portuguese food very often. I liked the food, the Calde Verde was very authentic but the dish we had for dinner was VERY salty. Also I would say the desserts were not impressive.
author: Megan L.

description:
My husband and I had a wonderful dinner at Uma Casa, celebrating our 16th anniversary. We arrived fairly early for our Friday reservation, so we sat at the bar to take in their cocktail menu. The Low Groan was by far our favorite; their version of a negroni.
