The atmosphere was vibrant and the ambience was lovely. Staff was friendly and attentive. Even Chef Telmo greeted us at our table...a nice personal touch, I think. Service was excellent, not feeling rushed at all.

I've never had Portuguese cuisine...Chef Telmo doesn't disappoint! We indulged ourselves with a combination of snacks, small plates, shared a large plate and ended, of course, with dessert. Chef Telmo, Thank You for sharing your talent with us! You definitely made our anniversary memorable! We look forward to coming back and eating the other half of your menu, ha! Saluté!
author: Abby S.

description: The dish selections are great and if you're looking to share family style, this is a good place for it. Out of all the (5) small dishes that I had, I would say that the picture below is the best. The rest were just a lot of plain and bland flavors that just didn't WOW me.
author: Lola M.

description:
**Update**  
04/2018 - We visited for our anniversary last month on the 29th of March.  We opted for the prix fare meals with the wine for about $60 a person.  This we felt was a good deal.  We had the Bolas Bacalau, Sardines, Bacalau a gomes sa, and frango com batatas fritas.  All was delicious except for the over salted problem.  This time it was way too much like Portugal where the dishes can be too salty that they become too much to finish.  I was saddened that last time it was not overly salty.  Please cut back 3/4 of the salt as it was the only disappointment this last visit.  (end of update)

This is a great addition to San Francisco that many of us Portuguese have been waiting for,(saudades) but for many of us we need to be aware before we go that this is not our grandmothers cooking, presentation, and nostalgia we are used to or in Portugal.  This is San Francisco's version of that and if you go with the expectations of delicious Portuguese food you will get just that delicious Portuguese food and wine.  I found many of the tastes and textures different from what is traditional, but every bite never disappointed. 

We started with the Pasties de Bacalhau which did not disappoint even though the texture is more smooth than what I was used to growing up and quite delicious.

The Grilled Sardines were cleaned and grilled to perfection and almost reminded me of the ones my grandmother would grill on the open flames.

The Mozambique Ship was delicious, but I think the version I make at home is a little bit better.  

Excellent Service and we hope to return soon.  Our dining date was February 03th.
author: Ray A.

description:
Pros: Octopus tapas and Shrimp Tapas
Cons: pretty much everything else- especially the wines by the glass, the deafening noise level, & the chocolate cake

Had high hopes but they failed to deliver on most accounts.
Not that it was "bad" per se- (although we all agreed the chocolate dessert was truly one of the worst things any of us foodies have ever eaten) but most of it was just OK- and for the prices not worth coming back for.

First of all the noise level was CRAZY loud. There was no way to hear the person on the opposite end of our table for 6 - much less the server. Yes it was packed on a Saturday night BUT some sound absorbing panels would go a long way in this place and they have the high ceilings to accommodate them.

Secondly the wines by the glass: The bubbles went over fine but my Wine Wife hated her selection which had an overpowering oak taste- very atypical for a Portuguese wine. I liked my selection.

The reds were almost universally despised- and we tried 4 different ones.
Lots of funky smells like barnyard and not much to them. The server obviously needed remedial wine recommendation skills since the one she chose for my Wine Wife - who told her she usually drinks lighter style Pinots- couldn't have been further from that style.

Suffice to say we didn't dare ask for a recommendation for a bottle, so I would recommend bringing your own wine ($25 corkage)- especially since the per glass prices were mostly $13-$16.

The short ribs (aka "Sopas") looked and tasted like ho-hum pot roast without any of the usual and expected creaminess and richness that makes this dish usually worth ordering.

The seafood risotto (aka "Arroz de Mariscos") was OK but nothing worth remembering and the portion was very small.
author: Stuart Z.

description: Lovely restaurant setting, pretty loud and vibrant. Our server was quite pleasant but you could tell was extremely busy and out main courses took an extremely long time to come out to which I don't fault the server. The food was ok but my dish the clams and braised pork in a tomato wine sauce w fingerling potatoes and cilantro really had no overall nice rich flavor profile and the pork was dry. 2 friends had the Robalo, pan roasted sea bass and enjoyed their meals. Another friend had the salt cod casserole and commented hers was ok. We also had the Salada Da Terra, beets turnips carrots citrus... which was good but needed something else going on to make it interesting.
author: Steven B.

description: Great $33 three course special Tuesday-Thursday. Awesome ambience and lively even on a weekday night. One of those places that would be absolutely always be packed if it was placed on a strip like Valencia or Divisadero, but being in Noe definitely makes it a tucked away gem and reduces wait time for you. The general manager Luca was the nicest guy ever and greeted our table personally! Food highlights included the cod/potato fritters and their egg tarts on the dessert side.
author: Justin C.

description:
I had the milho frito (polenta) with mushrooms and it was amazing. 
My friends had the bacalhau and said it was OK - nothing special. 
Bolinho de bacalhau, though, was delicious!
Mashed potatoes also delicious. 
Very friendly staff.
Bummer - they charged us a "cake fee" of $2 per person for bringing our own birthday cake. They didn't even let us know there was a fee to be payed.
author: Isabela R.

description: Loved the ambiance of this spot but none of the dishes stood out for me. We had the shrimp turnovers (ehh, soggy), the yellowtail seafood dish that was kind of like tartare (pretty good), octopus (pretty good), the ribeye special (cooked well but super salty), and the custard tart (pretty good). There was nothing we had that would make me want to come back, hoping they can add some better dishes or at least lay off the salt on some of their existing ones.
author: Shabnam E.

description: I'm as big a fan of soft candlelights and date nights ensconced in moorish tiles as they come, but $12 (+tax/tip) for 3 chicken wings is too hecking expensive. I feel played. Likewise $30 for a lukewarm skillet of half cooked little neck clams and some sausages in between - some of the clams even had the audacity to be semi-rancid! I really wanted to like this place but all this needs some work.
author: Ken H.

description:
Service: waiter was super pleasant and accommodating. They know how to treat their patrons well. I came here on a date and we had a wonderful time interacting with our man, who flitted in and out and made our dish decision making easier. 

Food: a. m. a. z. i. n. g. 
Pesticos (appetizers): we ordered the rissois de camarão (shrimp turnovers). the breading and dough was very chewy and gooey, but the filling was just alright. 
Pratos pequenos and pratos grandes (main dishes): 

you MUST order the "ervilhas com chouriço" (lamb chouriço/chorizo) if you're a lamb lover. the lamb bits were incredibly flavorful and tender, and the other ingredients paired with it (snap peas, soft boiled egg with runny yolk) were fantastic texture/flavor contrasts to the meat. 

2nd MUST have: the Linguado (pan roasted halibut, fingerline potatoes, beans, peppers, cherry tomatoes). oh my lord. the fish was tender on the inside and just lightly crispy on the outside. i think the best part of it was the slight vinegar taste in the light watery sauce - the light sourness paired very nicely with the white fish and veggies. this was the star of the meal.

dessert: sadly i don't remember the name of the desert, but it was a berry tart with pistachio gelato. classic good ol' berry goodness soaked into the buttery, crunchy crust wonderfully concluded our meal. don't forget to get a little scoop of the pistachio gelato for some good creamy balance. 

Interior: true to Portuguese style, in my opinion. I really loved how they used an actual stamp to brand their menus, which gave the restaurant a Portuguese rustic feel. It's also on the quieter side. Granted, I came on a Tuesday night. 

Parking/location: Noe Valley, and therefore quiet and easy to find parking. 

Takeaways: if you're looking for a good date spot and a creative, fresh, and light take on Portuguese food, definitely stop by Uma Casa. I'm definitely coming back with family and friends.
author: Vivian L.

description: I've been here countless times now and each time, the food + drinks are amazing. I also want to add that the staff is very accommodating of veganism; if you want more vegan options, ask your server! I've gotten soups and sorbets that weren't officially on the menu.
author: Morgane M.

description:
What an unexpected delight. Went shopping for Christmas goodies at Lehr's across the street and figured on stopping in at Pomelo afterwards. Well, they were not open for dinner so googled restaurants nearby and Uma Casa came up. Never been to a Portugese restaurant before so what the heck...
Everything was good from the home made potato chips to the salt cod fritters to the main courses. Pork chop and Risotto. Dessert was delicious. Had the lemon curd and the custard tart. 
Solid dining at the former Incanto location. Check it out... you likely won't be disappointed.
author: Ric W.

description:
Food 4 
        Beets Salad: 5. Good portion and presentation.
        Grilled Sardine:  4. The sardine was good but the side of onion was too sweet for my taste, I wish it was fresh onion with vinaigrette or someting.
        Garlic Shrimp:  4. 
        Armond tart with ice cream: 5. 
Drink 4
Ambience 5  I love their Lisboa themed interior! and the staff apron was so lovely
Service 5  Very friendly and attentive.
Price 4
author: Tory T.

description:
Let's say that I have history with Portugal, so as I learned that there was a new Portuguese restaurant in town, I brought my appetite along my lovely Karen, and off we went to Uma Casa. And "com certeza uma casa portuguesa" !!! (it is with certainty a Portuguese home)
The menu reads well, plus some of the traditional dishes that I adore.
Pasteis de bacalhau, Caldo verde, frango no churrasco, caldeirada, etc.
The staff seems all to be nice and jovial. The food came out nicely and flavors were there, nicely washed down with lovely Sagres beer. I am not into sweets that much, but couldn't miss pasteis de nata.
Will definitely be back for more !
author: Bruno S.

description:
I really wanted to love Uma Casa.  I experienced wonderful seafood and wine in Porto, Portugal, and was looking forward to having Portuguese food again.  However, the service and food fell short of my expectations.  Several misses by our server: she came to our table with a dirty bowl from another diner and then proceeded to stack our dishes and utensils on top of the dirty bowl, she filled only half our water glasses, and busboy dropped a knife in my mom's lap while clearing the table.  

Maybe it was an off night, but the cod fritters, arugula salad dressing and kale in sautéed halibut were terribly over-seasoned with salt. The breaded octopus was over cooked and too chewy.  The house made bread was tasteless and the butter that accompanied the bread was, surprisingly, lacking in salt.  Overall, the food was average and somewhat disappointing given the lack of execution by the kitchen staff. 

The atmosphere is loud and vibrant and was packed the night we went.  Unfortunately, given all of the misses we experienced, we won't return.
author: GP K.

description: Solid C + food.  Good tapas, and fresh fish entrees.  The entrees lacked a little in presentation.  Bill can add up fast with appetizers...not a great bang for the buck.  Popular place on weekends and reservations are required.
author: elissa s.

description:
Worst service ever! Don't allow people to make reservations at 9:30 if you're going to treat them like they are a burden. Let me start this off with the fact I was a pastry chef for 5 years; I would have to stay later than anyone in the kitchen and people were sat until 10pm in many cases. Late seatings suck, but never, ever where they served sub par food or made to feel that they were inconvenient. 

We sat at 9:40 and upon asking the server how he was were told "I'm alright" and told immediately that the kitchen was going to close. I get it, the restaurant closes at 10pm. You allow reservations at 9:30pm. You can tell me the kitchen closes 10 mins before it does...not right when I seat. It was a cold greeting and set the tone for the meal. 

We then went to order drinks about 5-7 mins later and were told that the bar was closed and that it was only beer and wine at that time! Another rushed, cold response from this restaurant. Why would you allow reservations at 9:30 if the bar closes then? You should not allow reservations that late if your amenities will be less than standard. 

The meal was underwhelming.... my short rib was lukewarm in the middle because the kitchen was rushing... the quenelles on the dessert were sloppy and made just of whipped cream. Either that's a poorly composed dessert or they put whipped cream on it instead of ice cream because they had put the ice cream away for the night. It was literally plain cake, strawberries and whipped cream. The cheesecake was lumpy because the cream cheese was improperly blended too...  We even made sure to order dessert right after we got our first starter plate to make it easier on the kitchen. 

To add the cherry on top, my birthday candle dessert was brought out while my best friend was in the bathroom. Huge serving no no. Uma casa, I am sorely disappointed and will not be coming back. I wish you were still Incanto.
author: Audra H.

description: Wow! I love this restaurant. Being from San Jose and Portuguese; I have a love of Portuguese food. This place really shocked me. I loved the appetizers, main course and dessert. Good portions and the quality is five stars. Prices are fair given the quality and size of the portions. I can't wait to go back. I had a great time there and loved the service.
author: Beatrice R.

description: We hosted a dinner at Uma Casa in their private dining room. Food from the fixed price menu was excellent - high quality and lots of it (we had leftovers). The wine selection was good and their events manager David was very good to work with before and during the event via email, text and in person. Finally the restaurant ambiance and decoration makes for a classy meal out that still has a warm and cozy feeling. As far as a meal goes: great food, drink, service and venue.
author: Gaurav V.

description: We tried several delicious  dishes , however two items was really not that great , the chicken was really overlooked and dry , don't order that , also the tart wasn't pleasant as well , service was great and beautiful dining atmosphere as well , will come back to try other things on menu
author: Heather Y.

description: The dishes are family style and a little like tapas, although the size of dishes vary from small to large. The food is excellent, lots of variety and vegetarian/pescatarian options. I especially liked their brussels sprouts and the Portuguese egg custard tart. Service is attentive. It is pricey, but you get what you pay for in quality of food, service, and ambiance.
author: Christina S.

description:
Cool joint. Great service. 

Food was pretty good and a bit different then the norm around here. Having had great Portuguese food many times I had high expectations. They were satisfied but not delighted. There were 4 of us and about a 50% hit rate on really good versus average. Will try again.
author: SR M.

description: Honestly I have just arrived home and couldn't wait to write this review... everything was perfect... we had cocktails and some bites to start... excellent WPT cocktails then we shared 5/6 plates between us, where to begin... the pulvo(octopus) was amazing! The salted cod dish was enough for 3 people and so so tasty... a nice bottle of red... then shared a dessert(nata) and port to finish... it felt like a proper European restaurant... it was a Tuesday night and super busy here so that should explain it all... all in all a must for those searching for a great meal
author: Reg B.

description:
Made reservations over a month in advance for a party of 6. Luckily we arrived before our guests as we were given the high top table in the corner with AWFUL aluminum stools. Tables more suited for a walk-in or quick bite, not a group planning to spend a nice evening out (who made reservations a month in advance)
When I told the hostess the table would not work for us she seemingly begrudgingly went to look for another spot. When she returned a few minutes later to let me know they had another table and asked if we still wanted to move I swear she rolled her eyes!
We were sat at a large table in the "private" room. From the the night totally turned around. The cocktails, food, wine and service were stellar. 
3 hours later we ended a wonderful night with family. Had we not moved we'd have been out a lot sooner. 
Note to self...when making a reservation state specifically not to be seated at the high tables. 
Note to restaurant...work on hostesses demeanor and get rid of those aluminum stools!!!
author: Us And J.

description: Date night with the wife...Wonderful!! Ambiance was very nice and rhe decoration is perfect for a Portuguese restaurant. We loved the food and the wine list. We will be back for sure! Kudos Uma Casa!
author: Paul G.

description: My husband and I enjoyed a date night at Uma Casa and it did not disappoint. From walking in with the decor of blues and whites it felt like we were in Spain or Portugal and was very inviting. The dishes are meant to be shared. They placed homemade chips with an amazing red pepper/tomato dip which was fantastic on our table to start. We started with the salada de mariscos which was a cold dish with shrimp, octopus, squid and garbonzo beans. The sauce on this dish was amazing. I loved the WPT White port cocktail. It was light and refreshing and paired wonderfully with the seafood. The Caldo verde soup was so good with leeks and linguicia- there was a slow heat that built up. Polvo Na Chapo was next and the pan seared octopus was amazing! Perfectly tender in a delicious sauce. Caldeirada was a delicious mix of shrimp, halibut, muscles and a delicious broth served with bread to sop up all that deliciousness. We ended with a pistachio ice cream on top of a peach tart. It's a great place especially if you are a pescatarian. We enjoyed a nice slow two hour dinner in a great atmosphere with great food.
author: Francine B.

description:
We came here to celebrate my husband's birthday. His friend is the owner/chef. The food was amazing the service attentive and the ambiance lovely. 

We started off with warm olives and the fried codfish- delightful. For our entrees my husband had the seafood medley and I had the braised short rib. So tasty and very traditional flavors. They start you off with homemade chips and a house salsa that is so unique. For dessert we had the cream tart and then the dark chocolate mousse with Maria cookie crust- so delicious!

The seating can seem somewhat close which I don't always like- but I was pleasantly surprised by the two guests that were seated next to us. Two gentlemen who were Portuguese and former presidents of Portuguese halls in the Bay Area. My husband (a Portuguese) began talking about childhood memories and such and we found out we know mutual people. It was so fun!

Overall- a very cozy, beautifully crafted restaurant with amazing flavors that brought my husband back to the islands. Great job Telmo! 

WE WILL BE BACK
author: Bethany A.

description:
Just Meh.

This place was intended to be a Portuguese cuisine with a modern twist. They get the modern aspect but completely miss on the authentic Portuguese cuisine. Being Portuguese, we wanted to love this so bad! Walking in the atmosphere seems nice, decorated with a small Portuguese touch, the tile on the walls gives it a great vibe. However, brunch was a complete miss. Walking in, we wish there was more Portuguese, the waiters were very friendly and overall made our experience better but they didn't really know Portuguese or what to recommend. The owner was also roaming around but went to his favorite tables literally every 10 seconds, why not greet everyone if you're doing that? We're all giving you the same business. Favoritism doesn't bring back new customers.

We tried a variety of plates on the menu, yet the "family style" options were still very small.


Overall, I honestly don't recommend this place, you can find better, more authentic  Portuguese restaurants. However, if you want to give this a try, be prepared because the portions are VERY small and VERY expensive. 


Sangria: White- did not taste good at all/not like Sangria is supposed to taste, it tasted more like a cocktail. Red- perfect!
Recommend: Bacalhau plate, Arroz Doce & Pasteis de Bacalhau.

Takeaways- Wish there was more traditional Portuguese dishes on the menu, more Portuguese music like Fado etc. Waiters that spoke or knew what the dishes were on the menu, the owner treating all customers equally.
author: Ann L.

description: Wow you must try this place , my mouth is jumping for joy. If you love flavors this is your place . Look at the starters . The dishes are so Beautiful, then the when it reaches your mouth , my  tastebuds Are Dancing and sings for joy and happiness . I'm in haven
author: Christen G.

description:
Overall walking in, this looked like a modern Lisbon restaurant. However, I have been to much more grand  Portuguese restaurants that have originality but still keep up the Portuguese traditions that make you feel as though you are in the Azores or the mainland. A lot of hype in the Portuguese community about this restaurant, gave it a try and didn't see all the hype at all, sadly.

Tile decorative walls are beautiful, the map of Portugal is also nice but expected to see more Portuguese employees. Many couldn't pronounce the Portuguese words on the menu. 

As for the Sangria - White was not good too fruity with the passion fruit, Red was much better 
(DID NOT REPRESENT THE TRUE PORTUGUESE WINE WE ALL KNOW) The Portuguese are big on their wine so this was a big fail.

From the plates our table shared, the Arroz Doce was the best.

Would have like to see more upscale Portuguese art from Azores/Portugal to make it truly feel inviting.

For non-Portuguese customers the menu is difficult to visualize as there are no pictures of the plates. This did cause confusion to a table next to me where the customer expected one thing and got another and had to send it back.

Was expecting the food to be more traditional with a little twist on Azorean and mainland food but was disappointed. It lacked the traditional foods you could find Grandma cooking in her kitchen.

The owner/head chef was rude only going to talk to some tables multiple times and not the rest of the others which didn't make myself and others as welcomed as we should have been.


Overall, would not return for the price.
author: Marie L.

description:
A-OK to meh. 

I'm not familiar with Portuguese food, but they had many items that were tasty. I love the idea of serving olives warm. We were told they served "family styles" and would keep items coming. They did a good job on that score. 

Service could use some serious improvement. Once they take your order and empty the wine, they drop the food off and are basically done with you. My daughter dropped her napkin directly in view of the waiter, but he simply left it there. Considering the pricing they could do a better job with the silverware. They just handle your used silverware, place it to the side (on the table directly), and continue. 

The place is very loud - you have to shout across the table to be heard. And the chairs are among the most uncomfortable my husband and I have ever encountered.  

Street parking only, but not too big a deal on a weeknight at 6:30.

I think they'll need to step it up if they want to last in SF. We'll likely not return.
author: Rita B.

description:
Food: 3 stars 
Service and ambience: 2 stars 

I can't speak to the authenticity (questioned by other reviewers) because I am inexperienced with Portuguese food, but we did mostly enjoy the meal. We liked the shrimp turnovers, reminiscent of Spanish croquetas. The caldo verde was also tasty. My husband thought the salada de terra was bland and the caldeirada a bit over seasoned. The bacalhau casserole had a really great combination of flavors, but it was dry and overseasoned. The pasteis de nata (custard tart) dessert was a tiny but delicious combination of creamy and sweet. 

Overall, the food was good, but not great. The service was friendly. The kitchen was terribly slow (25 minutes between the appetizers and the main). The place is loud, and the seating is uncomfortable. 

Also, sorry, but when your mains are $25-30, bring me new silverware between the appetizer and the main dish. Do not have the server pick my dirty silverware off the plate and lay it on the table. Gah! 

The place is new and if they get their act together, it could turn out well. But SF is a competitive town for restaurants, and status quo here will not secure a good future. 

We probably won't go back.
author: David K.

description: This place is very good, legit Portuguese food, I'm Brazilian.. pretty close  however been in SF 25 yrs and just found this place! Phenomenal.. want to bring all my family members and friends to check this place out
author: Aline M.

description:
One word: fresh, basically for the best experience in seafood. 
Super tasty oysters.. great quality ingredients, we love it! 
Bobby our sever was really nice and funny.. great service. 
Also Amazing wine selection.
author: Alan T.

description: Who is this place trying to fool? This is nothing taste like portuguese food. Im half portuguese i never had such nasty fake portuguese food in my life. Not to mention most of the food taste like spanish mexician, all the food are just made up from the chef's head of the taste. And everything is salty as hell. This place is an insult to portuguese food and should go out of business.
author: Weili C.

description: It was very mediocre food. I was recommended by a friend and we were visiting San Francisco. The service was good, the wine okay, but the appetizer, salad and main dish very bland with very little fish and way overpriced. I don't mind spending money on a good meal, but I was totally disappointed.
author: Anika P.

description: The lunch began with warm house made bread, butter and jam, which was a good start. Then came the Cod Fish fritters and shrimp empanadas which set the stage for the Shrimp Mozambique and Bacalhau, absolutely perfect. Then we finished it all off with Pastel de Nata sprinkled with cinnamon, best lunch in a long time. Will be back for dinner in the near future.
author: Linda N.

description: No bad. But the environment is too noisy; you have to be shouting to carry a conversation. Food is a bit on the salty side.
author: Earl C.

description: First, the cocktails! Although Uma Casa does not have a hard liquor license,the bar man is a genius making delicious and clever vermouth based cocktails. Try the shrimp turnovers with your cocktail. Octopus, cod, sardines, and piri piri sauces. Wonderful salads, spicy glazed chicken, all to share or not. Fun atmosphere, but very loud with the high ceilings..
author: Bj D.

description: Nice comfy space, perfect length of menu, unique food selections, Portuguese wine, great service. Issue overall was food is too too salty. Short ribs were delicious. Get them!
author: Andrew K.

description:
On the strength of a review by Patricia Unterman I went to Uma Casa despite the fact that it is relatively new.  The venue is large with immense windows that let in plenty of light.  Tiles on  the walls throughout the place give the restaurant a slight Moorish feel, which might not be inappropriate for a Portuguese restaurant. Service was friendly and relatively efficient although it took some time for food to appear from one course to the next.

Salada de rucula was composed of an immense portion of fresh arugula, sliced pears, cheese, and almonds.   The salad wasn't overly dressed and the vinaigrette wakened the appetite.  Lovely.

Seafood salad contained shrimp, octopus, mussels, and garbanzo beans.  Unfortunately, I was only able to taste the garbanzos as the assertive dressing simply overpowered the seafood.  This was an appetizer sized disappointment.

The shrimp in the seafood stew called "caldeirada" was fine whereas the sea bass was badly overcooked and dry.  The mussels in the stew had a slight taste of fishiness rather than a light briny taste of the sea.  The caldeirada was another disappointment to me.  

By the time that I left the restaurant was near full and there was an up-beat energy to the room.
author: David D.

description:
A mediocre restaurant. Their Portuguese dishes are totally not authentic. The way they make pasteis de bacalhau is like making crab cake which is totally wrong. Their Caldo Verde doesn't taste right to me either. And I don't see other famous Portuguese dishes in their menu, instead they blend in a lot of non-Portuguese dishes and fusion stuffs in their menu. It's almost like a mixture of Californian fusion.

Overall, I think it's good for people who haven't had real Portuguese food but definitely not for me!
author: Cory J.

description:
Chef Telmo Faria is going back to his Portuguese roots. After serving as exec chef for Tacolicious and Chino restaurants, the call of heritage with his modern twists are poised to make for a Portuguese restaurant in the near future. For now he's doing a couple of pop up series, one in Merigan Sub Shop and the other in American Grilled Cheese Kitchen. I caught one of the former ones which was a 5 course fixed meal

-Petiscos
House made queijo fresco, chouriço butter, Acme epi bread

-"Salada de Polvo"
Grilled octopus, summer beans, tomato, corn, potatoes, radish

-Bacalhau à Brás
Salt cod, egg, onion, straw potatoes, olive aioli, parsley vinaigrette

-"Carne de Porco à Alentejana"
Pork tenderloin, tomato-chouriço sauce, fried clams, potatoes, cilantro

-Tarta de Figo
Fresh figs, madeira lemon verbena custard, honey, cream gelato

Delicious all around. The lack of Portuguese food in the bay area is surprising. My friend who joined me for dinner grew up in Boston and the amount of Portuguese food relayed seemed like a whole different world to me. It's rare that ive gotten to try it with most of it being fairly traditional. Those flavors show up here with a twist of modernity. I look forward to a few more rounds of the pop up and the eventual restaurant in tow.
author: Kim N.

description:
This spot was a complete miss for me. I really wanted to love it but it seemed to have fallen flat. Didn't like their wine selection and really didn't like any of their entrees. Nothing was memorable. 

Lastly I just didn't like their wine selection and then decided to have a cocktail but the server told us that they don't have a liquor license which was a real bummer. The chef is well known and talented but I think the food needs more flavor.
author: Rohan D.

description: Came here for my mother's birthday.  We are Portuguese.  We had 5 different dishes and all of them were great.  Service was very good. Wines was also great, Alvaro Torte. I will definitely be back. It was a special birthday that we won't forget.
author: Mariano P.

description:
I went to Uma Casa for a late night dinner. The food is good. I highly suggest the Portuguese soup--it tastes like a Portuguese mama made it. We ordered a great bottle of wine. Unfortunately the menu is not on their website so I cannot name it, but since I am not familiar with Portuguese wines I asked for a Rhone style wine and they delivered. 

The oysters and sardines were fine. I would have like to have had some garnishes that enhanced both dishes. The cod fritters were good. The tuna salad was good. Everything was good. I want to give this place four stars, but I went to Bar Crudo the night before so I think I've just had a lot of seafood and I didn't have the appreciation of Portuguese cuisine that this place deserved. 

The interior is great and the service is fantastic.
author: Rosie F.

description:
I am happy that UMA CASA Restaurant opened its doors in San Francisco.  In NorCal, we only have two Portuguese restaurants in San Jose, Bacalhau Grill and Adega, one in Sonoma, LaSalette, and one in  Healdsburg, Café Lucia.  UMA CASA is a well-needed restaurant in the city.  
People ask me if these restaurants are the BEST representation of the Portuguese cuisine?  Probably the answer is NO but they are doing the BEST to exhibit the Portuguese cuisine and the culture.  We need to understand that the Portuguese cuisine is local traditionalist.  It will be impossible to have a restaurant that can represent the full spectrum of the Portuguese cuisine from Douro, Estremadura, Alentejo, Madeira, Azores and other regions. PLUS, the main ingredients cannot be found or import into the USA due to USDA restrictions in imports.  This means that chefs need to be creative and improvise the traditional dishes.  These changes are creating a new twist to the Portuguese cuisine called New Portuguese Cuisine or Ultramar Cuisine.  

UMA CASA is a GOOD example of  New Portuguese Cuisine.  The New Portuguese Cuisine utilize local ingredients to replace the original homeland ingredients by creativity and improvisation.  UMA CASA's food and ambient are REALLY good.  Portuguese restaurants are loud and full of energy.  If you go to a local GOOD restaurant in the Baixa, downtown Lisbon, o Porto this is what you get, busy, noisy social people.  If you plan to have a ROMANTIC, kissy-kissy, dinner, maybe this is not the place for you but if you announce everyone will cheer you up.  Sorry, they do not pay your bill.

To all my Portuguese countrypersons, we should support the Portuguese restaurants because they are promoting our culture and roots that is locking in the Portuguese community in the USA.  Because the food that you see in these restaurants does not look like your mother's or grandma's food, does not mean it is not GOOD or is not Portuguese food.  Remember, most of these chefs know what they are doing, of course, ones better than others.  Maybe the problem is that you do not know what Portuguese food is ... or your mother's or grandmas cook a variation or improvise recipe or a personal interpretation of the food ... or maybe they did not how to cook at all ... but not be criticizing something that you do not know and least you have the opportunity to put a foot in Portugal AND ... live, eat, drink and speak the language.  If you have done that, maybe you can criticize. 

In conclusion, we must support no only UMA CASA but all Portuguese's restaurants.  They are doing the best they can and we should be PROUD of these entrepreneurs.

CONGRATULATIONS
author: Joe C.

description: Love the location (finally a cool spot in Noe Valley), love the wine but as a vegetarian the options are very few. I see my friends enjoying their food though, which to me makes dining out worthy it! Hope they'll add some vegetarian options
author: Serena P.

description:
Hidden gem deep in Noe Valley.

Great food, great atmosphere, great wine. Have had great service at this restaurant when the servers were at the table (knowledgeable of wine, great recommendations), but sometimes could be hard to find when you need them (more water, etc). 

Eat family style and get different apps, small places, large plates and awesome deserts. Was great that we did not feel rushed to leave. 

Reservation needed!
author: Kathleen G.

description:
I had an altogether delightful meal at Uma Casa!

We had a nice mix of several things, sharing some dishes, like a shrimp dish, sardines (obvs), salt cod, etc.  Everything was delicious, well-balanced, and homey, yet elevated.

The decor really reminded me of Lisbon a lot what with all the blue and white tiles around, so it felt like a fairly authentic Portuguese experience.  They also seemed to have a fair selection of Portuguese wines on the wine list as I recall as well, which is a nice touch, Portuguese wines are great. (yeah it's California, yeah, we have wine country, get over yourself and experience the world of awesome wines...)

The four in our party shared two glasses of port and the restaurant kindly split them across two glasses each so we didn't have to share.  I love it when they do that, it makes me feel welcome.

This place is a delight!  Sadly I doubt I'll be back much; I'm moving out of the neighborhood soon and this feels like a neighborhood gem, but I highly recommend it!
author: Rachel S.

description:
Excellent addition to Noe Valley.  We have been waiting for a great restaurant to come our way and it is here.

It's lively and buzzy place.  The food is amazing - everything prepared beautiful to the eye and delicious to the taste.

The Chef adds a personal touch by coming by to the tables.  So down to earth and very appreciative to have people in his restaurant enjoying his food.  The staff are wonderful - everyone seems happy to be there.

Fabulous place.  We will certainly come again.
author: Gina C.

description:
New favorite spot in Noe Valley. Killer food and beverage program. I could live on the chicken and shrimp hot pockets (not their real name). Don't forget to order a salad! The arugula salad with pears and the seafood salad are a MUST!

I've been three times since they opened and it keeps getting better!
author: Kathleen E.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE!!!

I came here on their 4th day open and fell completely in love! What a great addition to SF, Portuguese fare! Delicious, especially the Rissois de camarao & the Pasteis de bacalhau. By the way, they serve the Portuguese sparkling wine from Filipa Pato, the sparkling Rose which is amazing and at a great price point!

Will go back for sure ;D
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Loved it! And yes, it (happily) is not authentic. We've visited Portugal and the first thing that hit me at Uma Casa was how come we didn't find any restaurants as good in Portugal itself? Probably because we went all banal with tired traditional restaurants. Not that there might not be any hipster places there; but if there are, I'll bet they're every bit as unholy and disgraceful as the absolutely fabulous food coming out of Uma Casa.

Everything we ate - short ribs, sardines and onions, green pea falafel, salad - was fantastic, and added to our go-to list.

Next time I go back, and I will be going back, if it delivers like the first time, I'm upping my review to 5 stars.
author: Bib G.

description:
Made a reservation over a week in advance for a 6:30p reservation on a Sunday. Arrived early at 6:15p, there were 2 women working the hostess stand and they said it would be a 15 min wait - no problem - and if we wanted a drink, we could go to the bar and order while we waited - also, no problem. 

We did order drinks; however, when it got to be 6:45p and the lobby was swamped with people with reservations, we began to get concerned. We had to check in with the hostesses and they said our table hadn't ordered dessert yet and we would need to wait another 15 minutes or more, I suggested they buy us a cocktail, which the manager did allow. 

Throughout our time at Uma Casa, it's extremely clear that the hostess team and manager do not know which tables are turning and how they relate to the incoming reservations. Throughout dinner, we saw the manager walking around the restaurant with the reservations iPad, looking around like she was completely befuddled as certain tables cleared and others were full.  Therefore - diners, beware - the restaurant does not know how to turn tables and it's curious that they have three people who are in charge of this who are totally clueless.

The free cocktails we had were very tasty (Zsa Zsa and WPA). Definitely worth trying an interesting cocktail - well executed. The food - we started with the cod fritters were tasty, served the right temperature and were good. Next, we had sardines - nicely prepared with balance achieved from the acid on the sardines. We then shared a bowl of caldo verde - awesome - definitely order this Portugese specialty. Fantastic blend of kale, potato, and linguisa. The large plate we shared was sea bass with garbanzo beans, potatoes, and salsa - nicely balanced with the fresh salsa. We ended with the Portuguese tart, impossible to cut with a fork in the small plate that it is served in, definitely pick it up and take a bite.

Long and the short of it - the restaurant does not know how to book and turn tables and what is particularly frustrating is that they have three people who are not communicating with their customers. A lot of this could be alleviated if they had their hostess and manager communicating with waiting customers and proactively serving up drinks to ensure that the rocky wait is worth the wait. If you decide to try this restaurant, do not be on a schedule and be prepared to ask for free cocktails as you wait...they won't be able to figure out that they need to do that proactively as they are looking around trying to figure out how the tables turn...

This is one of those places that could be a huge negative from the moment you walk in the door. This is unfortunate - the food is good. But if they can't up their service, we can all get better service going up or down the block in the neighborhood.
author: Nancy M.

description:
Being of Portuguese decent and having just come back from spending New Years in Lisbon, perhaps my expectations were too high.  I REALLY wanted to like this place, but there is work to be done before I return.

- Loved the facelift given to the space (former Incanto).  Lovely Portuguese beach town-like colors and materials.  Lots of light wood and blues.

- Service was friendly, but definitely sophomoric.  It's a new place and the team is still finding its groove, and it shows.  Multiple servers coming to our table asking the same questions, wanting to take our orders (even after we had already ordered), coming back because they forgot our order, etc.

- The wine list is very limited and the choices available are overpriced for the quality.  I buy a ton of Portuguese wine and I am familiar with a good portion of the selections on the list.  My guess is that it might be difficult to source better stuff in the Bay Area, but the mark-ups on what they did have seemed just a bit higher than usual.  I'm talking $15 wines going for nearly $50.  What disappointed me the most was anybody new to Portuguese wine would get the wrong idea from those selections!  Portuguese wines are much better than what was on the list.  However, the Port and tonic cocktail was great and very authentic.  We should have stuck to them.

- Finally to the food...  I am not going to dissect each dish we had. The menu itself was very traditional, which is a blessing and a curse.  I was happy to see familiar dishes but I also knew how they should be prepared.  I would grade each dish from a B (pork Alentejo style) to C (cod cakes).  I felt there was a general lack of seasoning and subpar execution (calde verde soup was very bland, cod cakes were bland and dry).  My sincere hope is the food will improve and evolve with time.  

The custard cake for dessert was a crime.  Having just eaten numerous "pasteis de nata" while in Lisbon (and even in Macau back in November) I know a good custard tart (and my waste shows it).  What Uma Casa is serving bears no resemblance to the Portuguese custard tarts I know and love.  Next time I would try a different dessert; they looked much better.

I'm going to give this place a couple of months before I return - it has promise.
author: B M.

description: Great food which I thought one could find only in Portugal! It saves you a trip to Europe if you're just looking Theo try Portuguese food.
author: Alex R.

description:
The location and atmosphere are great! We came pretty late (around 9:30pm) on a Saturday night and the place was fully booked. Luckily we got a seat at the bar wishing about 5 min. 

Wanting to try everything, we ended up ordering the first four dishes off the small plates menu (spicy shrimp, chicken wings, polenta with mushrooms and duck with risotto) to share between the two of us. The shrimp came out first and they were BOMB. The spicy, slightly sour sauce they were cooked in was amazing! I wanted to drink a bottle of it and slather it on everything I owned. The waiter brought over extra bread for us to finish up the sauce with, unfortunately our other waiter took our plates away (to my protest!) before the bread came out. 

The other 3 dishes were good, but not as memorable. Maybe because I was still thinking about those shrimp. The wings could've been cooked a little longer to get that char grilled taste. The duck with cherries was good, but I wasn't a huge fan of the risotto cake on the bottom. Polenta is normally one of my favorite foods, but the mushroom sauce was just a little too rich for my liking. 

I will definitely be back for the shrimp Mozambique though! They have a pretty good wine selection too.
author: Trena M.

description:
We live a block from this restaurant and have watched it move through its various iterations through the years.  This latest is, in my estimation, the best.  Though I've eaten a good deal of Spanish food, I've never had purely Portuguese, so I was looking forward to trying it.  The new décor works very nicely as they've replaced the heavy wooden furniture with a sleeker seating and painted the ceiling a mixture of blue and white creating an airy inviting vibe overall.  

Service was great as our waiter and support staff were never far not that we needed much.  
We began with the RISSOIS DE CAMARÃO (shrimp turnovers) that were quite good, crunchy on the exterior with a warm and tasty interior.  For our main course, my partner ordered ALCATRA (braised short rib) and I opted for the BACALHAU GOMES DE SÁ (salt cod and potato baked in a casserole) which is very similar to a Provencal brandade. We each enjoyed our choice very much.  

I was a bit surprised to read that some reviewers found the portions on the small side as both of us (and we have healthy appetites) left quite full.  In fact, I suspect two people could share the bacalhau.  We had no room for dessert, but the list was enticing.  As to wine, we chose a bottle of Quinta de Chocopahla Castelao that was quite good and paired well with both of our entrees.  We shall definitely return to Uma Casa. 
 
One final note:  we reserved at 6:00 and thought we might have an empty house around us.  However, that proved a misguided assumption as the place was hopping by 6:30.  So be sure to make a reservation especially if you want to visit on a weekend.
author: Nigel P.

description:
Food ****

Service *****

Venue/ambiance *****

The venue is welcoming and colorful. I loved the Portuguese ambiance. The service was great and our server was very knowledgeable and attentive. The food was good and the ingredients were fresh and tasty. I just wish that the Portuguese flavors develop a bit more as the restaurant gets more established.
author: Jaime Q.

description: Delicious delicious delicious!! Loved the atmosphere, the  service, and the food. Get the shrimp turnover appetizer.... caldo verde soup .....and pasteis de nata for desert. I am Portuguese and I was so impressed!
author: Andrea B.

description: Amazing, amazing, amazing! The food, ambiance, decor, and staff make Uma Casa a gem of the neighborhood. The Tues-Thurs 3 course special is also a great deal especially for the delicious food being served.
author: Otto M.

description:
Great food/service/ambiance!

The arroz de pato was delicious as was the pasteis de nata for dessert. Definitely get the cortum if you like spicy!
author: Derrik S.

description: Went back for the Caldeirada, the GF had the Frango Churrasco as well. Both of them exceeded expectations. This time they had Pasteis de Nata and I gave them a try. They seemed to me to be kind of a cross between two of my favorite Portuguese deserts, a traditional Pastel de Nata and a similar dessert, the Queijada (look it up) it was an interesting take that was still reminiscent of the dessert table at Community events and family parties. They have definitely hit they're stride 2 weeks in and I can't wait for future menus.
author: Eric F.

description:
I went to Uma Casa for dinner last night, and I can say Portuguese food and Chef Telmo Faria have a new fan.  

-  Food: Amazing. We had the chicken and the board with meats & cheese.  The olive oil citrus cake and pastel de nata for dessert were incredible as well.  

- Service: Great. Very friendly, not rushing us at all.

- Interior: Let's just say I could go back, just sit there, and I would be happy.  The wooden tables, perfect lighting and Portuguese tile make this place really inviting.  

- Price: If I just look at the number, I would say it is expensive. But it is worth every single penny. Value for my money and I we will be back again.  

If you can't get a reservation, they have a communal table for walk-ins, and my guess is that it will have availability often because there's not a lot of foot traffic in that part of Church Street, so worth the shot.
author: Fernando F.

description: Excellent food! We had a great dinner, didn't know what to expect but were pleasantly surprised by all the dishes. Salads were very refreshing, sardines had excellent taste and the desserts were delicious! Service and ambiance were great!
author: Niko P.

description: Awesome Portuguese restaurant with impeccable 5 star service. Immediately felt at home when we walked through the door, from the friendly hostess to the gregarious and lovely server who checked in on us several times through the night, asked us about ourselves, and regaled with his own stories. Even though we stated we weren't that hungry and stopped in for a quick snack, he still gave us 110% as though we were coming in for a full dinner. We got the baked salt cod casserole which was one of the most unique things I've had in SF in a long while. It was a soft, pillowy dish of salty goodness. The cocktails here are also include herbal/flowery/foresty flavors that complement the dishes well.
author: Linda T.

description: None of the dishes were stand out or exceptional in any way. Octopus dish was a little sparse as far as octopus is concerned and also tougher than we are used to. The sardines and seafood salad were ok, The egg for the lamb chorizo was overcooked, nearly hard boiled and the short rib dish was not short rib, but pot roast. The cuts are relatively close by, but are not the same. The four of us were not impressed and unlikely to return.
author: Easwud C.

description: I came here for a date night with the boy. I was tired from having worked all day. The restaurant entry way is warm and inviting. The tiles and the music all add to light hearted atmosphere. We shared some olives which were pretty standard mix of black and green olives, nothing distinctive. Then we shared bread with butter, and their specialty butters were yummy, but kind of expensive for what it was. Then we shared the octopus which was pretty tender and flavorful. We finished with the caldeirada. That stew was fantastic, extremely rich with lots of delicious seafood inside. My favorite part of the whole experience was the port here! Generally the portions are a bit small and the prices expensive for how much you get. The port though made the whole thing worth it, it is so amazing and you have to come experience of nothing else. May want to consider eating elsewhere if you are really hungry then doing dessert and after dinner drinks here!
author: Anne S.

description:
A wonderful addition to the neighborhood! Had the pleasure of tasting the absolute treasures produced from the kitchen. There is a lot of heart and passion that went into each dish that shows the chef's love of Portugal.
Food: I can't say what exactly was my favorite since it was all good. Uma casa shows their love and respect for seafood which is often hard to do! the bacaloao was extremely tasty. The team was able to embrace the freshness of the fish even after frying it. I'm pretty sure I could live off the shrimp croquettes and be set for life. Also another bit of magic by producing a fried item that tastes incredibly fresh (and lemony!). The ahi tuna was cute and prepared perfectly and we thoroughly enjoyed the bite of olive in the mix that provided the perfect amount of salt. I can't wait to return to spend an evening by the oyster bar. The non-seafood bites were equally scrumptious. The duck/risotto filled ball has a nice subtle duck flavor amongst creamy risotto and the Kale/mushroom empanada had a great filling and an absolute perfect crust. I adored the filling but I could have had the crust alone and still be happy.
Drinks: Delicious punches and a great wine selection
Scene: the restaurant is gorgeous. From first entering the space the open floor plan is very inviting and, according to Portugal natives, feels as if entering a local town restaurant. There is an attentive and friendly staff that I know will help make this restaurant a San Francisco favorite.
author: Alexis Y.

description: If they'd been open more than a week I'd deduct a star for running out of sardines and not serving octopus - we were looking forward to the reminders of our September Portugal trip. But it's early days and this is an impressive addition to SF and a nice vibe. Polenta cake delicious, so were clams, and the bacalau (sp?) tasted authentic. Friendly and professional service despite being jammed for an early Saturday night. Adding some curtains might help with the deafening noise. And the wine markup is 3x.
author: Robin W.

description:
I had visited Uma Casa popups before the brick and mortar spot was open and I was THRILLED when they finally opened the restaurant! Telmo (the chef) and company did such a wonderful job with this place. The decor is bright and airy and reminiscent of a beach-town cafe. The space itself is very enjoyable. The food is fantastic - the shrimp turnovers are incredible, the beet/root veggie salad is mind-blowingly simple and delicious, and the seafood is fresh and well-prepared. My favorite dish is the gambas. 

We've been twice and we will be regulars here!
author: Christina G.

description:
Outstanding new addition to our neighborhood! Uma Casa has a good vibe, with whitewashed walls and blue tile accents that have an authentic Portuguese feel. Background music ranges from international to Drake to Avicii. Diners hit every demographic---local families with small children, couples, groups and destination eaters. 

We had two different by-the-glass white wines, which were $9 and had nice acidity. Paired well with our arugula salad, white bean soup, gulf shrimp, quail and polenta cake. Everything was tasty, and portions were a perfect size. 

Service was professional and adept, which is saying a lot for a staff that was working in a packed room on only the second night in business. 

Chef Telmo Faria visited the tables and is a very nice, hard-working guy. Thrilled that we have a new, unique and excellent restaurant in Noe.
author: Eileen B.

description: Traditional, delicious Portuguese food and setting, yet also so fresh, bright and modern.
author: Carla H.

description: Beautiful ambience and creatively inspired dishes from Portugal. They have amazing staff and the head chef is spectacular! There also ate a fun neighborhood where you can walk around and do other activities around your dinner plans. Oh and I must not forget their amazing punches and wine list!!
author: Kim M.

description: Amazing 5 star dining experience, definitely recommend the salt cod fritters, appetizer plate, gulf shrimp and the home made bread! Definitely will be back!
author: Jessica R.

description:
3.5 stars

Atmosphere - Bring a jacket. It is cold in there. The majority of diners at 530 wore their jackets throughout the meal. Music, as another reviewer noted, is all over the place. When we sat I noted a nice rhythmic beat and then the next songs just made no sense. Sounds matter in a restaurant. While I enjoyed parts of the décor (wall mural) other parts just seemed slapped together. Stools used with the stand up tables are cold and do not convey a sense of come sit and stay a while. 

Service - Attentive and knowledgeable. A little too quick on the removal of plates. Typically a server should wait until all parties are done. Also the pacing of the dishes could be better as our appetizer came quickly but our mains lagged delivery for a while. 

Food - seafood "salad" (no greens) was cool and refreshing. short ribs delicious and perfectly cooked. Bacalhau nice dish and a big portion. egg tarts - delicious
author: C K.

description:
Had a terrible service experience. We showed up on a week day without a reservation and the hostess told us spots at the bar would open soon. Some opened indeed, but it appeared the hostess didn't pretend to manage the waiting list, and it was on customers to grab a seat as it became available. Couples that arrived after than us were "better" at jumping on opening spots.
Ended up leaving after a 30 minute unfruitful wait. After talking to management, it is clear the service staff doesn't match the level this place is pretending to have.
author: Sacha A.

description: Great food, drinks and dessert.  Loved the sardines and custard tart.  Was a bit loud and crowded during the peak times.  Parking wasn't as easy as initially thought. Service is good but wasn't over the top special for a special occasion.  Will be back though.
author: Neil F.

description: Phenomenal all the way around. Wide selection of Portuguese wines. Delicious food full of spices and flavor. Very healthy options- I had the halibut for entree and pickled vegetables for an app. This spot is a top maybe the top spot for me in SF!
author: Emma W.

description: Went here for a birthday with family and had a blast! Great drinks, amazing and unique food. Excellent service and the cocktails were very good. We were all happy and left with a smile. Will strongly recommend this place.
author: Dusan P.

description:
Don't bother, the food at uma casa was very disappointing. We had the cod fritters, sardines, bread and olives to start then between us had the chicken, halibut and another mediocre dish I can barely remember. Worst of all was the Portuguese tart for dessert which was completely burnt and inedible. Food wasn't authentic and the service was poor. 
If you are foodie, don't bother- you will leave disappointed like we did.
author: Allie S.

description: Great food! Did a la carte menu although the tasting menu also looked great. Want to return to try more items. We didn't have a reservation but sat at one of the community tables. We had the table to ourselves most of the night. Good service.
author: Donna L.

description: Fabulous food and wine and the company was y bad either. Cheers to Chef Telmo!  The cod fritters are excellent and the grilled corn is amazing.
author: L N.

description: Overpriced tiny portions. The dish I ordered was octopus and potatoes but what I got was a half empty plate with half a tentacle and one tiny potato cut in 4 slices for $16. I mean not even kids would get full there with 2 dishes. Besides that the place was so loud that you couldn't hear the person next to you.
author: Daniel B.

description: I was here last month with a small group of people and the service was excellent, the servers knew their jobs well, the food was very good too.   I liked the location of the city it is in as well and MUNI goes through that area as well.  The ambiance and the decor of this restaurant is beautiful too.  Keep up the good work.  Next time I am there in that area, I will stop in and eat again.
author: Ann R.

description:
I was afraid the food might be too chi-chi, but it was pretty down to earth and darned good.  We were able to get in without reservations; the torrential rains probably helped. It seemed that everyone who worked there stopped by to chat with us, including the owner. The complimentary homemade chips were spectacular. So were the desserts.

I live half a block away, so I'll definitely be back!
author: Robert C.

description: This place is priced as a Michelin star restaurant.  The food is good but prices need to go down.  $150 bill for 5 small tapas and 3 drinks is a bit steep.
author: Ruslan K.

description:
Fantastic! Came for girl's night and we loved everything we ordered. The dishes were delicious and hearty. The cocktails were tasty and unique. Our waitress suggested a wine that was great too. And the house bread...so good! The hostess was not friendly but the rest of the other three or four staff members we met were very nice and helpful. W hole we were there, a large party took over the tables in the front so it may be good for large groups. There is also a private room in the back that had about 12 seats but it was secluded. I hope this place makes it and I am excited to come back again.

What we ordered and shared family style (four ppl):

Ostras (Point Reyes) - fresh oysters and simple presentation

Milho Frito - crispy polenta cake with kale mixed into the polenta. 

Carne de porco - this was a stew with tender and juicy  pork. The house bread was perfect for soaking up the broth

We got one more dish with ground duck and fava beans which was my favorite.

Cocktail: WPT, Savages Island, zsa zsa, bamboo

Wine: Quinta de la Chocopahla, dark fruit, spicy, and rich and paired nicely with the pork and duck dishes.
author: Elisa T.

description:
I was so excited to go to Chef Telmo's Portuguese pop-up and boy was I impressed with the meal I had. We started with a fresh cheese and chorizo butter spread, accompanied by Acme baguette, and it was a delicious beginning.

The first official course was a grilled octopus salad, with corn and tomatoes and a few other things. The octopus was not chewy at all, and the whole salad was a variety of different colors and textures and flavors. It may have been my favorite dish. The presentation, like all that was to come, was beautiful.

Next up was a salt cod dish, which was also memorable for unique flavors and presentation. Everything worked together and was just wonderful. The entree of pork tenderloin with tomato-chorizo sauce and clams was just as good as everything that came before it. I can't keep using the same adjectives to describe dishes...just know that everything was awesome.

For dessert, it was a lemon-verbena custard with some time of shortbread-y cookie, gelato and figs. I am not a fan of figs so it was the only thing all night I left on the plate when I finished. But the rest was fantastic and not too sweet, and made for a great ending to the meal. 

Chef Telmo was talkative throughout the night, and explained a few dishes to us as they were brought over. I can't wait to eat his food again!
author: David B.

description: Real rating is a 4.5 due to slightly slow and awkward bar service, plus an overly salted main course. Otherwise, come here and enjoy the unique flavors of ! The meat and cheese plate was huge! Filled up 2 of us- and allowed us to try a few other small plates and just one main. The star of the show here is seafood for sure! The ambiance is great and the bar is first come first serve. There was about a 20 min wait for a table for 2 on Sunday night prime time so clearly this place is doing well.
author: Tiffany W.

description: Not particularly impressed. The arugula salad was basic but tasty and thankfully not overdressed. The standout dish were sardines - they were crispy and well-seasoned and the sauteed sweet onions accompanying them provided a good flavor balance. The main dish - a sort of potato, salted cod casserole topped with olives and eggs was so salty it was inedible. A custard tart for dessert was mediocre, definitely had better. Oh, and bring a sweater. The restaurant is freezing.
author: G H.

description: I ate here a few days ago, and everything-- literally everything-- we ate was absolutely delicious. I will be dreaming about the halibut entree and the cherries on the duck appetizer for years to come. Service was attentive but not oppressive, and the atmosphere was lovely. I highly recommend the vinho verde rose as an accompaniment to a great meal.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Came to Uma Casa with family, what a delightful friendly Portuguese Place. Uma Casa & This was just right. There was shrimp on ice at the front counter, there's chatter from every table, & a European feel over the entire Restuarant.
The waiter are realy great at explaining the menue and it was just right-- salted watermelon was the homemade soda flavor of the evening: an infinite amount of stars for a pretty pink sweet & salty drink that packs a flavor wallop. 
-- complimentary chips & a spicy peri peri sauce: You can I have an extra large portion to take home if you like and saver the meal the next day.
Food portions can be shared, Portuguese Friendly style.
House made bread with delicious chourico butter & olive butter; and Caldierada. 
-- elote: delicious, as to be expected 
-- gambas moçambique: shrimp with amazing garlic & white wine 
-- acatra: red wine braised short ribs, which tasted sweeter than we would've preferred. Will try the sea bass next time 
-- dessert: dark chocolate cheesecake, & peach & blackberry tart... Awsome, 5 stars for the sweets. Dont forget to try Natas, they are as close to Portugal as you can get, mum mum!!

We felt like we were in Europe and the food was awsome.
author: Elder R.

description: Wonderful food. Experience brought down by inattentive, overwhelmed servers.  Had to wait and wait and wait to be noticed so we could order ...anything. Frustrating for three dollar signs. Can someone start a business that teaches restaurants with potential how to train a functional team? Not sure if I'll be back.
author: Amber P.

description:
Good service and solid bustling ambiance. 

Wines were fun and interesting.  I would skip the cocktails until they get a liquor license. Random: good mocktails. 

Dishes were solid but nothing amazing. Desserts, however, were really good.
author: Amjad S.

description: Food was okay.  Nice space. Execution of the meal was a little disappointing.  Portugese food does tend to be a little salty, but this was a little too salty.  Octopus was a meagre portion and was very tough.  But this is one of the few Portugese restaurants in the city   If you're hungry for Portugese food  and want to taste some outstanding food, I'd recommend Adega in San Jose.
author: Jayne L.

description:
Everything tasted good. I took off two stars mainly for service and accuracy of the menu.

It was a long wait for everything. Placing drink orders. Getting samples of wine. Ordering the next course. Getting meals. Our meal took almost 3 hours. We constantly had to flag down our waiter and even just order wine from a busboy because we got desperate. 

Second, some items were a bit off. The Marisco salad was described as octopus, squid, a few their seafood items, and chickpeas. Instead we had a bowl full of chickpeas with a few pieces of shellfish. The half chicken similarly was quite small- 3/4 of the plate was lettuce and fries with two small legs. 

The flavors are there, but I wasn't impressed with the way it was run.
author: M. M.

description: Portugal in San Francisco! You can enjoy several plates from the Portuguese traditional culinary, all are very good. The wine choice and pairing are up to par. It's a warm and friendly space with personal attention
author: Carlos J.

description: It was nice to see this long-time vacant space finally get something new and interesting, and it's definitely one of our new favorites. The portions are generous, and the food is delicious. We ordered two items from the small plates section and two from the larger plates -- normally the minimum for a tapas-style dinner -- and we even had to take some of it home! The sardines and the cod fritters were awesome, and the grilled octopus and the pork stew were delicious and comforting. The wine selection is also a treat, and our server, Bobby, and the hosts were super nice and friendly.  It's our second time dining here and can't wait to return.  A great addition to our neighborhood!
author: Carlo A.

description:
We pretty much ordered everything on the menu
Here are my recommendations out of each course:
1- Cepa Pura Aragonez VR Lisboa 2013 (wine)
2- Gulf shrimp (entrée)
3- Short rib (main course)
4- Olive oil & citrus cake (dessert)
author: Sanam G.

description: What a fantastic trip to Portugal!  And we didn't leave town to do it!  Lovely, friendly service from the staff, especially Pablo!  They did much to make sure we were comfortable and attended to.  Every dish was beautiful And scrumptious, we will be back soon to sample more of the great menu.
author: Andy F.

description:
i really wanted to like this place.  Disclaimer: I am of portuguese descent.  Here is my experience:  
1. I was looking forward to having the Sardines... they were out.  I was looking forward to trying the Polvo... it is no longer on the menu.  So we chose a couple of other appetizers.  The cod fritters were good, so was the drink my wife ordered.   Then things started to fall apart.  The arugula salad we ordered came to the table missing the cheese it was supposed to have.  We had to ask for it, nonetheless, it was ok.  Kitchen mistakes are common in new restaurants.
2. Both my wife and I ordered the Bacalhau a Gomes de Sa.  Both dishes took 45 minutes to come to the table.  The server was very attentive and apologetic, but still, 45 minutes is a bit much.  
3. We tried to be very understanding because the restaurant is new and is clearly still trying to find its pace.  But once we got the dishes, mine was so overcooked that the dish was pretty much  "cod flavored mashed potatoes" (like a cod Shepherd's pie). I could not identify a single piece of fish or potatoes, it was all mashed together along with a lot of onions, I mean a lot of onions.  My wife's dish was a little better, you could see a couple of pieces of potatoes and some small pieces of fish, however she found a hair in her dish - yes, a hair - (which she didn't tell me about until we left), so she could not eat it.  
4. For dessert, we had the pastel de nata.  It tasted nothing like the original.  What was supposed to be a flaky dough was a caramelized shell I could not identify...what was supposed to be a smooth, creamy custard, was a lumpy super sweet egg filling of some sort. 
5. I also found the wine list to be very limited.  I tried the glass recommended by the waiter but didn't care for it, so I ordered a diet coke.   They don't have any diet/light/sugar free sodas.  Most restaurants in Portugal will have "coca light".
6. The music was loud and "pop like" and the space was super bright which I found to be very at odds with the concept.

Well, maybe I had the wrong expectations.   On a positive note, the staff was very friendly and responsive and the flavors are there.  They have a lot of work to do though when it comes to training the kitchen staff.
author: R X.

description: One of the few Portuguese restaurants in the Bay Area.  Well worth the visit as the food and drinks were all great, fresh and the ambiance just right. Make reservations inadvance if you can and I'd suggest family style eating so you can try more.
author: Richard L.

description:
Wandered over here on a Friday night without a reservation and was very pleasantly surprised. The host did her best to squeeze us in even though the restaurants appeared to be quite busy. 

The overall aesthetic of Uma Casa is very coastal Mediterranean and very well done. The large windows facing the street open up so that there's nice ventilation on warm nights. We felt that the service was great overall. Everyone was very attentive and friendly. With every dish that was brought out, a new set of plates and silverware were provided. Food seemed to be very authentically Portuguese and delicious. Will be returning in the near future!
author: Matt S.

description:
I really enjoyed my meal here with the family. The waiter was very helpful with understanding the menu choices. Every dish was fantastic. I can honestly say we enjoyed everything we tried together, all shared family style. 

The braised short rib was our favorite dish of the night.

We will definitely be returning again and again.
author: Art T.

description: Muito bom!!!! My first venture into Portuguese cuisine was a great experience. The food, the service, the atmosphere, and good friends combined to create a wonderful evening. I highly, highly recommend Uma Casa. You will not be disappointed.
author: Joe S.

description: We arrived there on Sunday around 5:20pm. Shortly after they open. Place got packed pretty fast, so I advise having reservations. The waiter was extremely nice and mindful. He suggested some drinks that were fabulous. Food is amazing and very similar to the Portuguese cuisine I know. Portions are a bit small for the price, but hey... it's San Francisco! And it was worth every penny.
author: Barbara O.

description: This place has a lot of heart. Food, service and ambiance were all top notch - everyone looked beautiful in the perfect lighting. :) I was a little apprehensive about Portuguese food but all flavors were approachable while also being adventurous and delicious. The short rib and octopus are absolute must try, as are the cocktails which are unique and balanced. Caveat about the cocktails - this place doesn't have a full liquor license, but more than satisfied. Staff felt dedicated in a way that is rarely felt in such a transient industry. Honestly worth the trip to noe - felt very homey and special at the same time. Bring a date, parents or friends. Do not come with someone you don't want to share an intimate experience with. Highly recommend.
author: Ashley C.

description: I was taken to this restaurant for my birthday as a surprise and I must say I was truly surprised.  The last time I had Portuguese food was over 20 years ago when I was in Portugal attending school in Italy. It was a refreshing surprise to walk into the restaurant, to be greeted by wonderful staff and to sample the great food. As a group of 4 we shared the shrimp turnovers, Grilled Sardines, Salt Cod Fritters (delish), Roasted Duck Breast and Shrimp, Octopus, Squid and Mussels. Everything was perfect. It made my birthday a very special one. Our waiter was outstanding too - I wish I could remember his name, but he had ginger hair and was super.
author: Mikael W.

description: Loved this place the first time I ate here. It was delicious and had great service. Then I tried to go a second time. I had a friend coming to town and talked up the restaurant quite a bit. I booked two weeks in advance and when I showed up with guest in tow, I found that the restaurant had cancelled my reservation sua sponte. No explanation, no solution. I was just given a curt apology and told to come back another time. Very, very disappointed.
author: Andrew J.

description:
Meh. We left the restaurant still hungry after many dishes. Portions were v little, flavors were v unimpressive, and service was just mediocre. We ordered the short ribs but our server thought we got the seafood dish and when we corrected him, he was sassy and dismissive of our concern! Did not expect this kind of service in such an establishment. 
The dessert (almond and pear tart) was the best part of the meal. Worth checking out if you have nowhere else to go in Noe Valley! :)
author: Victor N.

description: Outstanding food and service. Despite being very busy, the service was impeccable. All the dishes were creative and thoughtfully prepared. Delicious.
author: David T.

description:
My only criticism and comment to the owners is turn down the ridiculously loud (and IMHO inappropriate) music.
The food and service were very good, and the prices were reasonable.
I especially enjoyed the bacalao gomes which i've seen at only one other place in SF.  
Also the seafood salad with garbanzos was particularly good.
author: S K.

description: I went to Uma Casa with my 7 year old and my boyfriend. Gorgeous restaurant, beautifully plated food, and decent customer service. I think because they're new some of their wait staff maybe needs a bit of work but that's understandable. The food was great and the drinks were just as awesome !
author: Irene S.

description: Wow just finished dinner and it was amazing. The food was great and loved just hanging out at the bar. No need for a reservation, host snuck us right in. Will be back soon.
author: Khalid M.

description: Great food, great atmosphere. Definitely worth coming to. The food selection was great and new. Chef Faria had something to be proud of.
author: Jason F.

description: Unbelievable food! Definitely come here with a group of friends like we did. Every single dish from the appetizers to the desserts were incredible! Will be back!
author: Karen W.

description: Our new neighbourhood gem. Excellent wine selection from Portugal at great prices. Juicy cod, desserts and appetisers. Much recommended!
author: Alex M.

description: Came from two hours away to visit family and opening night at Uma Casa. Uma Casa has an authentic feel and look similar to restaurants in Lisboa and Azores. Great place for all ages and outings. Started with the sardines, excellent! Next, "Alcatra", braised short ribs, the duck and risotto also very good. Our waiter suggested bottles for our plates and he nailed with both. Chef Faria came by each and every table after dinner service to personally thank everyone for coming. For being an opening night I was surprised that service and timing of food were on point. Uma Casa is a must for all San Franciscans!
author: Christopher W.

description: Our experience was great at this restaurant. This is just what this area needs, an interesting, up beat, delicious and visually beautiful place to eat. Everything we had was delicious. We started with the butternut squash soup and what one would probably call a yellow tail tar tar. Both were fantastic. We then had the fried polenta with mushrooms in a madeira sauce....mouth watering...so good. We topped it off with a baked salt cod and potato casserole which was also great. Like i said, everything was fantastic. The bar staff were great too. Super attentive and made a some great drink suggestions. We are excited to have a great restaurant like this in the neighborhood and will be going there a lot.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Welcome addition to the hood that needs improvement 

Ok 3rd night open so I'll cut them some slack.  Noe is a food wasteland with a few exceptions so I more than welcome a concept like this, especially with a cuisine that's greatly underserved in SF.
